chapter.title: Acknowledgments
chapter.p: The guidance provided by Rabbi Abraham Lipshitz has greatly improved the quality of this translation. Much of the library work necessary to supply references for ibn Ezra’s allusions was carried out at Chesed L’Avrohom Nachlas David, where the books are nearly always properly shelved; a few of the rarer volumes were found at the Asher Library of the Spertus Institute. The English translation of Pentateuchal passages was influenced by Rabbi Charles Kahane’s Torah Yesharah. The Meḥoqeqey Yhuda of the late Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky served as primary commentary on the text, supplemented by the commentary of the late Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Netter. For a short period of time I had access to Abraham Lipshitz’s copy of the Weiser commentary, which was greatly useful.

My greatest debt, however, is to Abraham ibn Ezra himself, and to his teachers and their teachers before them, who preserved and clarified traditions dating back to Moses, and gave them over to the keeping of future generations.
The Translator
The Straightforward Meaning
[Sefer Hayyashar]
by Abraham the Poet
Firmly Rooted in the Intricacies of Grammar
May It Serve The Cause of Correct Understanding and May It Gladden All Who Use It

p.i: O my God, the God of my sire Abraham,
Grant kindness to me, to Your slave ABRAHAM.
May the words of Your wisdom be taught to the ear
Of Your servant, THE SON OF Your servant ME‘IR.
And may Your salvation come down from afar
To the person whose title is IBN ‘EZRA.

chapter.title: A Point of Law
chapter.p: Jewish law forbids one to accept payment for teaching Torah. Yet this book is not being given away — it is being sold. One must not conclude from the behavior of the publisher, however, that an individual is permitted to draw a salary for teaching. Several factors combine which possibly render the sale of this book permissible:

1) The cost of printing books is not directly proportional to the number of books printed. Publishing entails both fixed costs and variable costs. Certain initial expenses — e.g., setting up the plates — must occur no matter how many copies are made. Other expenses — e.g., buying paper — depend on the size of the printing. Thus, unless you can predict exactly how many copies you will sell, it is impossible to establish a selling price that guarantees neither a profit nor a loss. Consequently, a sufficiently popular book will necessarily make money, while a sufficiently unpopular book will necessarily lose money, and there is no way to avoid both possibilities simultaneously.

2) The prohibition against teaching Torah professionally extends only to the oral Torah (tora sheb‘al peh). One is permitted to collect a fee for teaching the written Torah (tora shebikhtav). Although this book contains tora sheb‘al peh, it also contains tora shebikhtav; the portions of the book which may be sold are inseparable from the portions of the book which may not be sold.

3) The author of the book has been dead for several centuries and will collect no earthly royalties from it. The only people collecting royalties will be the publisher and the translator. Translating someone else’s teachings is not the same thing as teaching something yourself, therefore it may be forbidden to do the latter, but not the former, for money. (This reason is probably the weakest of the four. Every translation is perforce an interpretation. Ibn Ezra himself often called the early Sages the ma‘atiqim.)
4) A book is a physical commodity. Conceivably, giving a lecture falls under the definition of “teaching”, but selling a commodity does not fall under that definition.

The absence of any of these four factors would have rendered the sale of this book of questionable legality. In fact, the legality of the sale ought still to be considered questionable. I do not hereby supply a psaq din, and no one should derive a hetter for similar behavior either from my actions or from their defense.

It should go without saying — but perhaps it must be said — that these words must not serve as a pretext for criticizing the well-intentioned actions of any other human being. Observing Hilkhot Talmud Tora, 1:7, does not allow one to disregard Hilkhot De‘ot, 2:3. Whoever uses the above point of law to justify feelings of disrespect or disdain commits a crime far more serious than any which I have here tried to prevent.
The Translator

chapter.title: Dəvarim
chapter.p: In the Name of the One Who speaks Truth to the Just,
Who creates, and directs, and disposes —
I begin my attempt to explain and discuss
The fifth of the Five Books of Moses.

[1:1]These are the words which Moshe addressed to all Israel beyond the Jordan River, in the wilderness, in the desert, across the Red Sea, between Paran and Tofel, and Lavan, and Ḥaṣerot, and Di-Zahav. [2]It is eleven days from Ḥorev by way of Mount Seir to Qadesh Barnea. [3]At the end of the fortieth year, on the first day of the eleventh month, Moshe addressed the children of Israel as to all that GOD had commanded him concerning them. [4]After he had defeated Sihon, the King of the Amorites, who was seated in Heshbon, and Og, the king of Bashan, who was seated at Ashtaroth, in Edrei. [5]Beyond the Jordan, by the land of Moab, Moshe began to expound this Torah, saying: [6]“GOD our God spoke to us in Ḥorev, saying: ‘You have tarried enough at this mountain; [7]turn away, move out! Come to the hill country of the Amorites and its neighboring countries. Go by the plain, in the mountains, in the lowland and the Negev, by the seashore until you reach the land of the Canaanites and Lebanon, as far as the great river, the river Euphrates. [8]Mark! I am giving over the land before you. Come and inherit the land which GOD promised your forefathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob to give to them and to their descendants after them.’ [9]At that time I said to you: ‘I am not able to lead you alone. [10]GOD, your God has increased you, so that today you are as many as the stars in heaven. [11]— May GOD the God of your fathers multiply you a thousand times, and bless you as He promised you — [12]How can I single-handedly bear your troubles, and your burden, and your strife? [13]Propose men from each one of your tribes, wise men, people of understanding, well-known, and I shall appoint them as chiefs over you.’ [14]You answered me by saying: ‘It is a good suggestion which you have proposed.’ [15]So I took the heads of your tribes, wise and renowned men, and I appointed these chiefs over you, captains of thousands, captains of hundreds, captains of fifties, captains of tens, and officers, for your tribes. [16]I cautioned your judges at that time, saying: Listen between your brethren and execute justice between a man and his neighbor, and between landlord and tenant. [17]You must not recognize any person in court cases; you must listen to the small the same way as to the great; you must not fear any personality, for justice is of God; but the case that is too difficult for you, you will bring to me, and I will hear it. [18]I myself instructed you at that time in all the things which you must practice. [19]We marched from Ḥorev through all that vast and fearful wilderness which you saw, on the way to the Amorite highlands, just as GOD our God directed us, and we arrived at Qadesh-Barnea. [20]When you came to the hill-country of the Amorites, which GOD our God had given us, I said to you: [21]‘Look! GOD your God has set the land before you; arise, occupy it, as GOD the God of your fathers has told you. Have no fear, neither be alarmed.’ [22]But all of you approached me and pleaded: ‘Let us send men ahead of us to delve into the land for us, bring back a report of the route for our invasion of the land, and of the cities against which we should move.’ [23]The matter pleased me, so I selected twelve of your men, one man for every tribe. [24]They left, went up into the mountains, and came to the valley of Eshkol and explored it. [25]They took some fruit of the land with them, brought it down to us with their report stating: ‘The land which the GOD our God has given us is a good land.’ [26]But you refused to go up; you rebelled against the promise of GOD your God. [27]You protested in your tents, saying: ‘Because GOD hated us, He brought us out of Egypt to destroy us by delivering us into the hands of the Amorites. [28]Why should we go up? Our brethren have broken the courage of our heart by telling us that the people are greater and taller than we and the cities are larger and fortified up to heaven. Moreover, the Anakim giants are seen there.’ [29]Then I pleaded with you: ‘Do not panic and be not afraid before them, [30]GOD your God who goes before you, He will fight for you, just as He did before your eyes in Egypt; [31]and in the wilderness, where you have seen how GOD your God carried you as a father carries his son, throughout the way that you went until you arrived at this place.’ [32]Yet on this occasion you did not trust in GOD your God, [33]who went before you on the way, to seek out a place for your encampment. He leads you by a pillar of fire by night to show you which way to go, and in a column of cloud by day. [34]When GOD heard the sounds of your words, He was angry and decided: [35]‘None of these men — not the entire evil generation — will see the good land which I promised to give your fathers — [36]except Caleb, the son of Yephunneh; he will see it, and I will give the territory upon which he trod to him and his children, for he had followed the will of GOD.’ [37]GOD was angry with me also on your account, saying: ‘Neither will you enter there. [38]Joshua the son of Nun, who stands before you, will go there. Strengthen him, for he will allot it to Israel. [39]Moreover, your little ones whom you said would be plunder — your children who on the day did not know to distinguish between good and evil — they will go there, and I will give the land to them; they will occupy it. [40]But as for you, turn back and march through the wilderness in the direction of the Red Sea.’ [41]You answered me: ‘We have sinned against GOD. We will go up and fight as GOD our God commanded us.’ Each of you armed himself with weapons of war and you essayed up to the hill-country. [42]But GOD said to me: ‘Warn them. Do not go up or fight, for I am not among you, that you not be defeated by your enemies.’ [43]So I spoke to you and you did not obey; but you rebelled against the warning of GOD, and wantonly went up toward the hill-country. [44]Then the Amorites who lived in the hill-country came out to meet you and chased you as do the bees. They crushed you at Seir, until Ḥormah. [45]You returned and wept before GOD; but GOD did not hear your voice, and He was not attentive to you. [46]So you stayed in Qadesh many years, as the days when you stayed. [2:1]We then turned back, and marched through the wilderness in the direction of the Red Sea, as GOD told me to do; and we circled mount Seir a long while…

[2]GOD said to me: [3]‘You have gone around this mountain long enough; turn toward Canaan, northward. [4]And instruct the people as follows: “You are to pass along the border of your kinsmen, the Children of Esau, who dwell in Seir; they will be afraid of you, but you be careful — [2:5]do not provoke them, for I will not give you even one footstep of their land, because I have given mount Seir to Esau as an inheritance. [6]You may buy food from them, with money, that you may eat; and you may also buy water from them, with money, that you may drink. [7]For GOD your God has blessed you in all your actions; He has overseen your march through this vast wilderness; these forty years GOD your God has been with you, you have lacked nothing.”’ [8]So we by-passed our kinsmen, the Children of Esau, who dwell in Seir. We took the route of the desert, from Elath, and Etzion-Gaver,

then turned and passed by way of the wilderness of Moab. [9]GOD said to me: ‘Neither besiege nor provoke them to war; for I will not give you any of their land as an inheritance, because I have given ‘Ar to the descendants of Lot as an inheritance.’ [10]Its original inhabitants were the ’Emim, a great, numerous and tall people as were the Anakim — [11]they, too, were considered Refaim, like the Anakim, but the Moabites call them ’Emim. [12]Seir was originally inhabited by the Horites, but the children of Esau dispossessed them by destroying them from there, and dwelt there in their stead just as Israel is doing to the land of his inheritance, which GOD has given them. [13]‘Now, arise and pass the brook of Zered!’ So we passed the brook of Zered. [14]The time from when we started marching from Qadesh-Barnea, until we passed the brook of Zered, was thirty-eight years, during which all that generation of military age expired from among the camp just as GOD had sworn to them. [15]Moreover, GOD’s hand was against them, to annihilate them from among the camp, till they expired. [16]When all the military-aged men among the people had expired —

[17]GOD spoke to me: [18]‘You are about to pass, now, the border of Moab — the territory of ‘Ar; [19]you will come toward the Children of Ammon, do not besiege them, and do not provoke them; for I will not give you any of the land of the children of Ammon as an inheritance, because I have given it to the descendants of Lot as an inheritance.’ [20]That, also, is considered the land of the Refaim. It was originally settled by the Refaim, whom the Ammonites call Zamzummim, [21]a people great, numerous, and tall as the Anakim. But GOD destroyed them, and they succeeded them, and inhabited their land, [22]as He did for the children of Esau who occupied Seir when He destroyed the Ḥorites from before them, and they succeeded them and dwelt in their stead to this day. [23]But the Avvim who dwelt in open towns as far as Gaza, the Cretans who came forth out of Crete destroyed them and occupied their land. [24]‘Arise, march on, and pass over the brook of Arnon. Mark! I have given Sihon the king of Heshbon, the Amorite, and his land into your hand. Begin to occupy! Challenge him to war. [25]From today on I shall spread your dread and fear upon all the people that are under the whole heaven. Whoever hears of your fame will tremble and be in anguish because of you.’ [26]I sent messengers from the wilderness of Kedemoth to Sihon the king of Heshbon, peaceful messages, saying as follows: [27]‘I would pass through your land. I will go by the road, only by the road. I will not turn either right or left. [28]You will sell me food for money, that I may eat, and give me water for money, that I may drink, only let me pass through in my march — [29]as the children of Esau who dwell in Seir did for me, and the Moabites who dwell in ‘Ar — so that I may pass the Jordan into the land which GOD our God gives us.’ [30]But Sihon, the King of Heshbon, refused to let us pass through him; for GOD your God hardened his spirit, and made his heart obstinate, in order that He might deliver him into your hand, as you see it today.

[31]GOD said to me: ‘Mark! I have begun to hand over Sihon and his land to you; begin the occupation; take possession of his land! [32]Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to wage war in Jahaz, [33]and GOD our God delivered him to us, and we defeated him, his sons, and all his people. [34]When we had conquered his cities at that time, we exterminated in every town, the men, the women and the children; we left no survivors. [35]Only the cattle did we take for booty, together with the other spoil of the cities which we had conquered. [36]From Aroer, which is on the edge of the brook of Amon, and the city which was built on the brook, up to Gilead, there was not a city too strong for us; GOD our God rendered everything to us. [37]Only against the land of the Children of ‘Ammon you did not approach any area, all along the river Jabbok and the cities of the hill-country, and all the places which GOD our God has commanded us not to conquer. [3:1]We turned, going up through Bashan, and Og, king of Bashan, came out against us — he and all his people — to battle us at Edrei. [2]But GOD said to me: ‘Do not be afraid of him, I will deliver him, all his people, and his land into your hand; and you will do to him as you have done to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who dwelt in Heshbon.’ [3:3]So GOD our God also gave ‘Og, king of Bashan, and all his people into our hand; we defeated him without having left him any survivor. [4]We conquered all his towns at that time. There was not a city which we had not taken from them: sixty towns, all the ’Argov group in the kingdom of ‘Og in Bashan. [5]All these were fortified cities with high walls, gates, and bolts, apart from the very many open towns. [6]We exterminated them as we had done to Sihon king of Heshbon, exterminating every town — the men, the women, and the children. [7]But all the cattle, and the spoil of the towns we retained for ourselves. [8]At that time we took the land out of the domain of the two Amorite kings in the eastern Jordan, from the brook of Arnon to Mount Hermon. [9]The Sidonians call Hermon Syria, and the Amorites call it Senir. [10]All the cities of the plain, the entire Gilead and the entire Bashan, even Salcah and Edrei, the capitals of Og in Bashan. [11]Only Og, king of Bashan, remained of the remnant of the Refaim. His bed, an iron bed, is still preserved in Rabbath-Ammon; its length is nine cubits, and its width four cubits, of a man’s cubit. [12]The land which we occupied at that time — from Aroer, which is on the brook of Arnon, and the half of the hill-country of Gilead and its towns — I gave to the Reubenites and to the Gadites. [13]The rest of Gilead and all of Bashan, the kingdom of Og, indeed, all the royal provinces of Bashan — which is called Refaim land — I gave to the half tribe of Manasseh. [14]Ya’ir the son of Manasseh received all the capital royal provinces of Bashan, as far as the border of the Geshurites and the Ma‘akatites, and named them after himself: Havoth Ya’ir of Bashan to this day. [15]To Machir I gave Gilead. [16]And that which I gave to the Reubenites and to the Gadites, was from Gilead to the brook of Arnon, within the brook, and boundary, and to the river Jabbok, which is the border of the Children of Ammon; [17]the desert also — and the Jordan and bank — from the Lake of Galilee to the sea of the desert, the Dead Sea, under the Spring of Pisgah eastward. [18]I commanded you at that time, as follows: ‘GOD our God gave you this land for a possession. All your warriors must pass as a vanguard before your brethren the Children of Israel. [19]Only your wives, your children, and your cattle — of which I know you have in abundance — will stay in your cities which I have given you. [20]Until GOD lets your brethren settle down as you and they too occupy the land which GOD your God is giving them on the West side of the Jordan, then may you return, everyone of you, to his inheritance which I have given you.’ [21]I also instructed Joshua at that time: ‘You have seen with your own eyes all that GOD your God has done to these two kings; so will GOD do to all the kingdoms toward which you are crossing. [22]You must not be afraid of them, for it is GOD your God Who fights for you.’

[23]At that time I begged grace of GOD, as follows: [24]‘GOD! You have begun to show Your servant Your greatness, and Your mighty power. There is no other power, either in heaven or on earth, who can perform such deeds as You, and so mighty as Your might. [25]Let me, please, cross over and see the good land which is in the western part of the Jordan, the goodly mountain land and the Lebanon.’ [26]But GOD, Who was furious with me on your account, did not heed me, and GOD said to me: ‘Enough! Do not speak anymore to Me about this matter. [27]Ascend the summit of Pisgah, and direct your eyes westward, northward, southward, and eastward, and see it with your eyes, for you will not cross over this Jordan. [28]Instruct Joshua, strengthen him, and encourage him — for he will cross before this people, he will allot them the land which you will see.’ [29]So we stayed in the Gai, across Bet-Peor.
chapter.ftnote: [1:1] The correct interpretation of These are the words is that the commandments written in the upcoming parashiyyot of Rə⊃eh, Shofəṭim, Ki Teṣeh, and Ki Tavo had already been given to the Israelites when they were in the wilderness. In other words, the phrase that Moshe spoke is modified by the entire remainder of the verse, as if Scripture had repeated it, saying: “These are the words that Moshe spoke to all Israel, which Moshe had spoken in the wilderness, and in the desert across the Red Sea…” starting from the day that they left Sinai. between Paran and Tofel, and Lavan, and Ḥaṣerot, and Di-Zahav These places are either not mentioned in the parasha of Mas⊂ey, or they are mentioned under different names. Many places have several different names (e.g., Mount S̀ənir has three other names [cf. 3:9 and 4:48]).

[2] Scripture says eleven days to tell us that Moshe spoke these words during those eleven days wherein they traveled from Ḥorev to Qadesh Barnea⊂. I shall later inform you that the spies started out from Qadesh Barnea⊂ [comment on :3] [see also Numbers 32:8]; after GOD swore that they would not enter the land, no new commandments were given until the fortieth year — for so it is written [Bava Batra 121a–121b] [Ta‘anit 30b] [cf. 2:16–17]. Conclusive evidence is found in the phrase “to expound this Torah” [:5]: He explained the Torah that he had already spoken between Paran and Tofel. Note that most of the Commandments are repeated in this book. Accordingly, the upcoming phrase “all that GOD had commanded him concerning them” [:3] is properly modified by the preceding phrases “across the Jordan” [:1] and “in the desert wilderness” [:1]. If you can grasp the mystery behind the following problematic passages: 1) The final twelve verses of this book 2) “Moshe wrote…” [31:22] 3) “At that time, the Canaanites dwelt in the land” [Genesis 12:6] 4) “…In the mountain of GOD, He will appear” [Genesis 22:14] 5) “behold, his bed is a bed of iron…” [3:11] you will then understand the truth. ¶ There are those who say that the reason for mentioning It is eleven day’s journey from Ḥorev, by way of Mount S̀e⊂ir, to Qadesh Barnea⊂ is to stress that they wandered in the wilderness for forty years — hence, the contrasting phrase

[3] in the fortieth year. This interpretation is incorrect, because they came to Qadesh Barnea⊂ in the second year [:19]. The phrase in the fortieth year actually modifies the phrase “Moshe spoke” [:1].¶ Some people assert that Moshe died on the first of Shəvaṭ. They claim that after the nation mourned over Moshe for a period of thirty days [cf. 34:8], they remained there for approximately six more weeks [cf. Joshua 4:19]. Their evidence is the phrase “that same day” [32:48] — that is to say, they maintain that Moshe recounted this entire book to all Israel on a single day, and then died. This evidence is invalid, however, because “that same day” refers only to the recitation of the song. Besides, Scripture says elsewhere “you are soon [literally: today] to pass over the Jordan” [9:1]. ¶ I have already explained the word on the eleventh in the parasha of Nas̀o [comment on Numbers 7:72].

[5] Moshe began [and] expounded Scripture employs two consecutive verbs in the past tense, without a connective vav. Compare “turned away [and] was gone” [Song of Songs 5:6]. Moshe began to expound to the children born in the wilderness what had happened to their parents. He told them all of the laws. He also repeated the Ten Commandments — for, their parents having heard them from GOD, Moshe was desirous that they too should be able to hear them from a faithful representative.
[6] Ḥorev is Sinai, as I have explained [comment on Exodus 17:9].
[7] The phrase move out [literally, “move to you”] is an instance of a Hebrew idiomatic form. Compare, “go out” [literally: “go to you”] [Genesis 12:1].
[9] I am not able alone Compare, “you are not able to perform it by yourself” [Exodus 18:18].
[10] has increased you in Egypt, thus fulfilling the blessing given to their ancestor [Genesis 26:4] [see also Genesis 28:14]. The comparison to the stars in heaven is figurative.
[11] Here the noun times appears with the number a thousand; elsewhere, it appears with the number “one hundred” [II Samuel 24:3]. In both cases the word order is opposite that of Arabic.

[12] your hardship as in “they are a trouble to me” [Isaiah 1:14]. This is the hardship of making foolish people understand the Commandments. your burden i.e., their demands for bread [Numbers 21:5], and water [Exodus 17:2] [cf. comment on Exodus 17:2], and meat [Numbers 11:4].
[13] Propose is an irregular word, for the heh is properly vocalized with a ḥaṭaf pattaḥ. That they should be known means that everyone should recognize them.
[15] I have already explained captains of thousands [comment on Exodus 18:21].

[16] The word listen [Hebrew: shamoa⊂] is a verbal noun, like “Remember [Hebrew: zakhor] the Sabbath day” [Exodus 20:8]. The meaning is understood as if it were followed [Hebrew: shamoa⊂ shim⊂u] or preceded [Hebrew: shim⊂u shamoa⊂] by a verb in the imperative mood. I have already explained the word his tenant [comment on Genesis 15:13].
[17] You must not recognize i.e., to tip the judgment toward the person whom he recognizes.
[18] which you must practice i.e., the statutes and laws which were taught to them.

[19] all of that wilderness traversed during the abovementioned “eleven days” [:2]. Scripture uses the term Amorite highlands because of the subsequent passage, “in S̀e⊂ir, and until Ḥormah” [:44], and because we were to go to the Amorite highlands [see :7].
[21] inherit a peh-yod verb (like “dwell” [Genesis 20:15]), from “inheritance” [2:5]. be alarmed an ‘ayin-‘ayin verb, as in “the glory of Ya⊂aqov shall be made thin” [Isaiah 17:4].
[22] delve into as in, “delve into all of the land” [Joshua 2:3]. To delve is to find that which is covered. against which we should move i.e., against which we should move first.
[23] the matter pleased me on account of your unanimous approval of it.
[25] brought it down because of the height of the tree. Actually, however, the term is used because the people were in the South.1
[27] you protested as in “they that murmur shall learn doctrine” [Isaiah 29:24]. The verb is in the nif‘al form, like the verb in “do not be aggrieved” [Genesis 45:5].
[29] do not panic, i.e., “do not fear”. The word denotes an unnerving kind of fear, as in “let Him be your dread” [Isaiah 8:13].
[30] fight for you i.e., He will fight on your behalf.

[33] for your encampment This is not a transitive verb in the hif‘il form. We find no evidence that this root even exists in such a form. However, in the word to show you, the lamed is vocalized with a pattaḥ to indicate the absence of the letter heh — just as when there is an elided definite article.
[36] The yod in except is extraneous. The word is also found without a yod [II Kings 24:14]. I shall give him the territory upon which he trod i.e., Ḥevron [Soṭa 34b].

[37] I have already explained [comment on Exodus 2:2] that in the word “His anger” [Hebrew: ⊃appo] [e.g., Genesis 39:19], a nun is absorbed in the peh. This is evident in the Aramaic cognate. Thus, the word is from the same root as “though you were angry [Hebrew: ⊃anafta] with me” [Isaiah 12:1] and GOD was angry [Hebrew: hit⊃annaf] with me also.
[38] Scripture mentions Calev first [:36], as I have explained [comment on Numbers 14:30; see also comment on Numbers 14:24], and then Joshua who stands before you — he was Moshe’s minister.
[39] who on the day did not know In those days, they did not know good and evil. Scripture describes most, not all, of the children.

[41] and you essayed [Hebrew; vattahinu] You said, “aye!” [Hebrew: hen]. (Do not wonder that a verb can be derived from a particle. The same occurs with the particle “upon”. We also find the word “I hesitate” [Hebrew: ’afunah] [Psalms 88:16], from the particle “lest” [Hebrew: pen], as I have explained [comment on Psalms 88:16].) Some say that the word comes from “hin”, which is a unit of volume — but this is farfetched.

[44] The Amorites came out These are the abovementioned “Canaanites” [Numbers 14:25], as I have explained [comment on Numbers 14:25]. as do the bees When someone approaches their hive they instantly chase after him and sting him. crushed [Hebrew: vayyakktu] As I have explained, this word is related to “I will beat down” [Hebrew: vəkhattoti] [Psalms 89:24]. until Ḥormah the name of a place — or, it could be a verbal noun [meaning, “destruction”].

[46] you stayed in Qadesh i.e., Qadesh Barnea⊂ many years, as the days when you stayed You stayed as many years as you spent days in spying out the land (any refutation of this on the grounds that only the spies themselves were guilty is repudiated by the supporting verse “According to the number of the days you have explored the land” [Numbers 14:34]).
[2:5] do not provoke [Hebrew: titgaru] them as in “stirs up [Hebrew: yəgareh] strife” [Proverbs 15:18].

[6] you may buy food from them if they wish to sell. Some say, however, that it is a rhetorical question, as if to say, “you have not needed food nor drink all these years that you traveled”; this is borne out by the continuation

ftnote.b: [7] GOD your God has blessed you.

chapter.ftnote: [9] I have given ⊂Ar i.e., the territory of Mo⊃av (most likely it ultimately returned to Mo⊃av after Siḥon conquered it [Numbers 21:28]).
[10] Scripture informs us that the Moabites took ⊂Ar from the ⊃Emim (I have already given the etymology of the name ⊃Emim [comment on Genesis 14:5]).
[11] I have already given the etymology of the name Rəfa⊃im [comment on Genesis 14:5].
[12] The Ḥorites are the descendants of “S̀e⊂ir the Ḥorite” [Genesis 36:20].
[15] to annihilate them an ‘ayin-‘ayin verb in the qal form.
[16] The phrase when all had expired… is connected to the upcoming verse
[17] GOD spoke to me1: After all were finished dying, GOD said
[18] that we should pass the border of ⊂Ar.
[19] You will come toward the Children of ⊂Ammon i.e., when you will come toward them. do not besiege them an ‘ayin-‘ayin verb. do not provoke them an unaspirated lamed-heh verb in the hitpa‘el form.
[20] The word Zamzummim is inflected according to the rules of the Hebrew language into which it has been assimilated. Compare, “the satraps” [Esther 8:9].
[21] GOD destroyed them Scripture describes how GOD destroyed other nations in the face of the Moabites in order to give them the land for an inheritance,
[22] just as He gave Mount S̀e⊂ir to ⊂Es̀av.

[23] as far as Gaza. This is mentioned because the region had once belonged to the Philistines, and a covenant was in force between Abraham and Avimelekh (“you will not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my grandson” [Genesis 21:23]). Scripture thus relates that the ⊂Avvim had taken Gaza [Ḥullin 60b].
[24] Begin to occupy [Hebrew: resh] From “inheritance” [Hebrew: yərushah].
[26] from the wilderness of Qədemot In my opinion this is the same wilderness as the one called “Mattanah” [Numbers 21:18].
[27] by the road The road, i.e., the well-known road.
[28] You will sell me food for money, that I may eat if I have a need.

[29] as the children of ⊂Es̀av did for me
Some commentators relate this phrase to “you will sell me food for money” [:28], but if this be so, how can they reconcile it with the inhabitants of ⊂Ar, who are Moabites, and of whom Scripture says “because they did not approach you …” [23:5]? They feel constrained to give this interpretation, though, because the king of ⊃Edom said, “you shall not pass through me” [Numbers 20:18]. In my opinion, the phrase refers back to the request that we go along the main highway, as the children of ⊂Es̀av did for me — i.e., they let them go around Mount S̀e⊂ir along the main highway. Scripture accordingly related, “You are to pass along the border of your kinsmen, the Children of ⊂Es̀av, who dwell in S̀e⊂ir” [:4]. However, the king of ⊃Edom did not let them pass through by way of his territory (from which point they would have been close to the land of Canaan), so they went on to ⊂Ar — as it is written [:18]. Many others have proposed that, although “they did not approach you” [23:5], nevertheless Israel did purchase from the Moabites.

[31] I have begun [Hebrew: haḥilloty] The inflectional prefix heh is vocalized with a pattaḥ on account of the subsequent guttural consonant. Compare, “I have raised him up [Hebrew: ha⊂irotihu] with justice” [Isaiah 45:13].
[33] The word we defeated is missing the initial nun of the triliteral root.
[34] the men i.e., male humans.
[36] strong [Hebrew: s̀agvah] from “GOD alone shall be exalted [Hebrew: nis̀gav]” [Isaiah 2:11].

[37] the land of the Children of ⊂Ammon i.e., the land that presently remains in their hands, as I have explained [comment on Numbers 21:24]. you did not approach any area [literally: any arm] The word means “place”, as in “the side [literally: the arm] of the Jordan” [Numbers 13:29].
[3:3] having left him [singular] that is, every one of the Israelites (the verb is in the past tense).

[4] the ⊃Argov group The words of the Aramaic translator [“royal cities”] are well-known. Others say that ⊃Argov is the name of a man whose patrimony contained this group. Still others assert that the ’alef is extraneous, and that the word is distantly related to “the clouds [Hebrew: rəgavim] cleave fast together” [Job 38:38].

[11] a man’s cubit i.e., a normal man’s cubit — thus indicating that he was twice an ordinary man’s size (it is implausible that Scripture meant his own cubit, because then Scripture would be telling us nothing about his size — and moreover, it would imply that he was not at all shaped like a human being).
[14] I have already explained [comment on Numbers 32:41] that Ya’ir the son of Mənasheh was actually from the tribe of Yəhudah. Geshurites and Ma⊂akatites are the names of two nations.
[15] Makhir has been previously introduced [Numbers 32:39–40].
[16] brook, and boundary i.e., and its boundary. Compare,
[17] the Jordan, and [its] bank.

[18] Although Moshe spoke only to the tribes of Reuven and Gad, he said I commanded you because they were a constituent part of Israel. Moshe speaks synecdochically in the opposite sense when he says to the Levites (in the passage beginning with “Take this book of the Torah” [31:26]) “For I know your rebellious nature” [31:27]: He was not then speaking only to the Levites, but to all Israel. However, since the Levites were included, he continued to address them.

[23] I begged grace i.e., I had already begged grace. Scripture has just mentioned [:21] Moshe’s instructions to Joshua; but Moshe instructed Joshua only in consequence of “I will not cross [with you]” [4:22]. I did indeed beg GOD’s grace to cross over with you, because the greatness of GOD “is unsearchable” [Psalms 145:3]; and “They are new every morning; great is Your faithfulness” [Lamentations 3:23].

[24] The intention of the following passage is to endear the Land of Israel; for if the land is cherished, they will keep GOD’s commandments so as not to be exiled from it. You have begun He said: You are infinitely wise, for You have begun to show … Your greatness … in heaven and on earth, through natural events. Your mighty power Moshe refers to the signs which he repeatedly performed, until it was known throughout the world that there is no God other than Him alone: prepotent in heaven (home of the angels and the Heavenly Host) and on earth (home of animals and men). deeds which are wholly wise might i.e., You are capable of anything.
[27] Ascend the summit of Pisgah identified with “the Gai in the fields of Mo’av — the summit of Pisgah” [Numbers 21:20]

[29] we stayed in the Gai i.e., we had already stayed in the Gai (which was near the “summit of Pisgah”), since from there we went to the plains of Mo’av. The passage is explained correctly by assuming that the Gai forms part of the hills of ⊂Avarim [Numbers 33:48]. Moshe now begins to talk about the commandments; and, since they were across Bet-P⊂or, he begins by discussing idolatry.

1[This must not be misunderstood to mean that in ibn Ezra’s time and place, maps were conventionally oriented with North on top (they were not); it seems to be only a reference to the fact that the land of Canaan is generally higher in altitude than the lands South of Canaan — Translator]
1Compare, “When Moshe completed writing…” [31:24], “on the day when GOD spoke…” [Exodus 6:28], and many similar instances.

chapter.title: Va⊃etḥannan
chapter.p: [4:1]And now, O Israel, obey the decrees and the judgments which I teach you to do, so that you may live, and enter, and occupy the land which the God of your fathers is giving you. [2]You shall not add to the words which I command you, neither shall you diminish from it, in order to preserve the commandments of GOD your God which I instruct you. [3]You have seen with your own eyes what GOD did with Baal-Peor; for all the people among you who followed after Baal-Peor, GOD your God annihilated, [4]but you who cleaved to GOD your God are alive, all of you, today. [5]Mark! I have taught you decrees and judgments as GOD my God commanded me, for you to observe within the land which you enter to inherit. [6]Observe them and practice them, for this is your wisdom and understanding in the eyes of the people of the world, who on hearing of all these decrees will say: ‘Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people.’ [7]For what great nation is there whose God is near them, as is GOD our God whenever we call upon Him? [8]Or what great nation has righteous decrees and laws, as in all this Torah which I set before you today? [9]Only watch yourself, and guard well your life that you never forget the things which your eyes have seen, and let them not depart from your memory throughout your life time. Transmit to your children and their descendants: [10]the day when you stood before GOD your God in Ḥorev; when GOD said to me: ‘Assemble the people to Me, and I will communicate My Words to them so that they learn how to revere Me, as long as they live upon the land, and they shall transmit them to their children.’ [11]You gathered and stood at the foot of the mountain. The mountain burned with fire in the heart of heaven, amid darkness, cloud, and mist. [12]GOD spoke to you from out of the fire. You heard the sound of words, but you saw no image, only a voice. [13]He declared to you His covenant when He commanded you to observe the Ten Commandments, and He inscribed them on two tablets of stone. [14]At that time, GOD instructed me to teach you decrees and judgments, that you perform them in the land toward which you are crossing to inherit. [15]Be, therefore, very careful for your lives, since you did not see any image on the day that GOD spoke to you on Ḥorev from amidst the fire — [16]that you do not ruin, by making for yourselves a graven image depicting any figure, whether of male or female form, [17]or the form of any beast which is on the earth, the form of any winged fowl which flies in the sky, [18]the form of anything that creeps on the ground, the form of any fish which is in the water under the earth, [19]and that you not raise your eyes toward the sky, and see the sun, the moon, and the stars — all the heavenly bodies — and be drawn away to worship them or to serve them, for GOD has allotted them for all the nations under all the heavens. [20]GOD took you, and brought you out of the iron furnace of Egypt; to be to Him a chosen people as you are on this day. [21]But, GOD was angry with me because of your words, and vowed that I should not pass the Jordan and not enter the good land which GOD your God is giving you as a heritage. [22]For I must die in this land, and I will not cross the Jordan; but you will pass over, and inherit this good land. [23]Be careful, then, not to forget the covenant which GOD your God made with you, and make for yourselves any statue or image, as GOD your God has commanded you. [24]For GOD your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.

[25]When you rear children and grandchildren in the land where you are well established, and you corrupt your ways by making a statue of any image, or do evil in the sight of GOD your God so as to provoke Him, [26]I call upon heaven and earth as witnesses against you this day that you shall perish swiftly from the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess. You will not remain long in it, but will be utterly destroyed. [27]GOD will disperse you among the peoples, and you will be left a minority among the nations to which GOD will drive you. [28]There you will serve idols — the work of man’s hands — of wood and stone, which neither see, nor hear, nor eat, nor breathe. [29]But from there you will seek GOD your God and you will find — if you pray to Him with all your heart and with all your soul, [30]when you are in distress because all these things happen to you, in the end of the days, when you return to GOD your God and obey His commandments — [31]that GOD your God is a merciful power He will not abandon you and He will not destroy you, nor will He forget the covenant He affirmed to your forefathers. [32]For study the history of ancient times, which were before you — since the day that God created man upon the earth, and from one end of heaven to the other — and see whether there has been such a grand thing as this, or if there has been heard the like of it. [33]Did ever a people hear the voice of God speaking out of the midst of fire, as you have heard and survived? [34]Or has God ever attempted to come and take for Himself a nation from the midst of another nation, by miracles, by signs, and wonders, by war, by mighty power, by outstretched arm, and by great terror, all the things which GOD your God has done against the Egyptians before your very eyes? [35]You have been shown with certainty that GOD is God; there is none other beside Him. [36]Out of heaven He made you hear His voice to discipline; upon the earth He has shown you His great fire; and you have heard His words out of the midst of fire. [37]And because He loved your fathers, and chose their descendants after them, therefore He has brought you out, in His face, with His great might from Egypt, [38]to drive out before you, greater and mightier nations than you; to bring you there and give you their land for an inheritance, as this day. [39]Know today, and impress it upon your hearts, that GOD is God in heaven above and upon the earth beneath; there is no other. [40]Observe His decrees and His commandments which I instruct you today, so that He will bestow kindness upon you and your children after you, and that you may endure a long time upon the land which GOD your God is giving you for ever.”

[41]At that time Moshe set aside three cities of shelter in the eastern side of the Jordan, where the sun rises [42](so that a manslayer might escape there — he who murders his fellowman unintentionally, who was not his enemy in the past — he may escape to one of these cities, and live): [43]Bezer in the wilderness, in the flat land, which belonged to the Reubenite tribe, Ramoth in Gilead, which belonged to the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashon, which belonged to the Manasseh tribe. [44]The following is the teaching which Moshe proclaimed before the Children of Israel; [45]these are the commemorations, the decrees, and the rules which Moshe told the Children of Israel when they came out from Egypt, [46]across the Jordan, in the ravine over against Beth-Peor — in the land of Sihon, the king of the Amorites who was seated in Heshbon and whom Moshe and the Children of Israel defeated after they had left Egypt. [47]They occupied his land and the land of Og, the king of Bashan, the two kings of the Amorites which are in the side of the Jordan where the sun rises, [48]from Aroer on the bank of the brook of Amon, as far as mount Sion, which is also called Hermon — [49]and all the desert beyond the Jordan, eastward as far as to the sea of the desert, under the springs of Pisgah.

[5:1]Moshe called out to all Israel, and said to them: “Hear, O Israel, the decrees and the rules which I speak before you today, that you may study them and observe to practice them. [2]GOD our God entered into a covenant with us in Ḥorev. [3]Not with our fathers did GOD enter this covenant, but with us; we who are here today, who are all alive. [4]Face to face GOD spoke to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire. [5]But you were afraid of the fire and did not ascend the mountain, so I stood between GOD and you at that time to declare to you the word of GOD, saying:

[6]‘I am GOD your God Who took you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage. [7]You shall not possess any deity beside Me; [8]you shall not make for yourself any sculpture, nor any image of anything that is in heaven above, or that which is on the earth below, or that which is in the water beneath the earth. [9]You shall not worship them, nor serve them; for I, GOD your God, am a jealous Power, remembering the sin of fathers upon children, even upon the third and fourth generation, of them who hate me, [10]and showing kindness to thousands to those who love Me and keep My commandments.
[11]You shall not take the Name of GOD your God in vain, for GOD will not clear him who takes His Name in vain.

[12]Observe the Sabbath day, by hallowing it, as GOD your God has commanded you. [13]Six days you shall labor, and do all your work, [14]but the seventh day is a Sabbath to GOD your God: you shall not do any work, not you, nor your son, nor your daughter, nor your man-servant, nor your maid-servant, nor your ox, nor your donkey, nor any of your livestock, nor your sojourner within your gates, so that even your slaves shall rest as you. [15]For you must remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, and GOD your God has brought you out from there with mighty power and with an outstretched arm, therefore GOD your God has commanded you to observe the Sabbath day.
[16]Honor your father and your mother, as GOD your God commanded you, that you may have length of days, and that it may go well with you, on the land which GOD your
God gives you.
[17]You shall not murder.
You shall not commit adultery.
You shall not steal.
You shall not bear fraudulent witness against your fellow.
[18]You shall not be jealous of your fellowman’s wife;
You shall not desire the house of your fellowman, his field, or his servant, or his maid-servant, his ox, or his donkey, nor anything which belongs to your fellowman.’

[19]These words GOD spoke to all your assembly at the mount, amidst fire, cloud, and mist with a mighty voice, that has not continued. He wrote them on two tablets of stone and gave them to me. [20]When you heard the Voice out of the midst of darkness, while the mountain burned in fire, all the heads of your tribes and leaders approached me, [21]and said: ‘GOD our God has shown us His Glory and His magnificence; and we have heard His voice from within the fire; we have seen today that a mortal can survive though God has spoken to him. [22]Now, why should we die, when this great fire consumes us? — if we continue to hear the voice of GOD our God any longer, then we shall die. [23]For who is there among mortals who has heard the voice of the living God speaking from the midst of fire as we have, and survived? [24]You go closer and listen to all that GOD our God may say, then you will communicate to us all which GOD our God has spoken to you, and we shall obey and practice.’ [25]GOD accepted your plea that you spoke to me, and GOD said to me: ‘I have heard the voice of this people’s words, which they have spoken to you. All they have spoken has been agreeable. [26]Oh, who would grant that they had such a will as this always, to revere Me and keep all My commandments, so that it may be well for them and for their children forever. [27]Go, tell them that they may return to their tents. [28]But you stay here with Me, and I will speak to you all the commandments, the decrees, and the judgments which you will teach them, how they will practice them in the land which I give them to possess.’ [29]Now observe to practice as GOD your God has commanded you. Do not turn aside to the right or left, [30]follow all of the path that GOD your God directed you, so that you may survive and do well, and you will remain long in the land which you are going to possess. [6:1]Now, these are the instructions, the decrees, and the judgments which GOD your God commanded me to teach you, to perform in the land into which you are crossing to inherit, [2]in order that you will revere GOD your God by observing all His decrees, and His commandments, which I instruct you, your son, and your grandson, all the days of your life, and in order to assure you long life. [3]Obey therefore, O Israel, and observe to practice it; so that He may treat you kindly, and increase you greatly — as GOD the God of your forefathers has promised you a land flowing with milk and honey.

[4]Hear, O Israel: GOD our God is one GOD. [5]You shall love GOD your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your might. [6]These words which I instruct you today shall be on your heart. [7]Repeat them over to your children; speak of them when you sit in your house, and when you travel on the road, when you lie down, and when you rise. [8]Bind them as a sign upon your arm, and let them be frontlets between your eyes. [9]You shall write them upon the door posts of your houses and on your gates.

[10]When GOD your God brings you to the land which He promised to your forefathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, to give to you: spacious and prosperous cities which you have not built; [11]houses full of all good things which you have not filled, cisterns cut from rocks, which you have not hewed, vineyards and olive trees which you have not planted, and you eat and are satiated — [12]beware, that you not forget GOD Who took you out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage. [13]Revere GOD your God; Him shall you serve, and by His name shall you swear. [14]Do not follow other gods, from the gods of the nations that surround you. [15]For GOD your God, Who is in your midst, is a jealous Power. Let not the anger of GOD your God burn against you, so that He wipe you off the face of the earth.

[16]Do not test GOD your God as you tested Him in Massah. [17]Keep always the commandments of GOD your God, and His commemorations and His decrees, which He commanded you. [18]Do what is right and good in the sight of GOD, so that He will treat you well when you come and inherit the good land which GOD your God promised to your forefathers, [19]when He will thrust out all your enemies from before you, as GOD had spoken.

[20]When, in the future, your son asks you: ‘What are the rituals, the decrees, and the rules, which GOD our God instructed you?’ [21]You shall explain to your son: ‘We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt, and GOD brought us forth from Egypt with mighty power; [22]GOD inflicted great and terrible signs and wonders upon the Egyptians, upon Pharaoh, and upon all his household, before our own eyes. [23]He brought us out from there, in order to bring us in and give us the land which He affirmed to our forefathers. [24]GOD commanded us to practice all these decrees to revere GOD our God, to bring happiness for us always, and to preserve us as we are on this day. [25]It will be our privilege to observe to practice all these commandments before GOD our God as He commanded us.’

[7:1]When GOD your God will bring you into the land which you come to possess, and will fell many nations before you — the Hittites, and the Gergoshites, and the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Perizites, and the Hivites and the Jebusites, seven nations greater and mightier than you — [2]and GOD your God delivers them before you, and you defeat them, you must utterly proscribe them; you shall not conclude a treaty with them, neither shall you show them any consideration. [3]You shall not intermarry with them, you must not give your daughter in marriage to his son, nor may you take his daughter for your son, [4]for he will turn your son away from from following Me, and they will worship other gods. Thus will the anger of GOD burn against you, and He will destroy you quickly. [5]But thus shall you deal with them: Demolish their altars, smash their monuliths, cut down their Ashera trees, and incinerate their idols in fire. [6]For you are holy people to GOD your God. GOD your God has chosen you out of all nations on the face of the earth to be His beloved people. [7]GOD did not attach you nor choose you because you were numerous among the nations, for you are indeed the smallest of peoples. [8]But out of love for you, and out of His keeping the oath He made to your fathers, did GOD free you with mighty power and redeem you from the house of bondage, from the power of Pharaoh king of Egypt. [9]Know, therefore, that GOD your God is the Almighty. He is the faithful God, Who keeps the covenant, and the kindness, for His beloved, and for them who keep His commandments, for a thousand generations.. [10]He repays His enemies to his face, to destroy him; for His enemy He does not defer, he repays him to his face. [11]Therefore keep the commandments, the decrees, and the rules which I instruct you this day to do.
chapter.ftnote: [4:1] teach you to do The ultimate purpose of study is the performance of the commandments. so that you may live for all those who worshiped P⊂or were destroyed. so that you may occupy [Hebrew: viyrishtem] Since the yod is absorbed into the ḥiriq of the preceding vav, the second consonant of the triliteral root exhibits progressive assimilation and also has a ḥiriq. No other Hebrew word has this property.
[2] You shall not add i.e., you shall not add your own ideas, thinking that you thereby serve God. Likewise, you shall not diminish.

[3] There is no need for witnesses to substantiate the warning “so that you may live” [:1], because You have seen with your own eyes what happened with Ba⊂al P⊂or (i.e., because of Ba⊂al P⊂or — as in many other Hebrew words):
[4] Everyone who did not worship Ba⊂al P⊂or is now alive.

[5] I taught you Moshe has already said “…which I teach you” [:1]; but here he adds as GOD commanded me. The commandments are His commandments, which you are to perform in the land He gives you for an inheritance. Moreover,
[6] you shall have glory among the nations through the commandments. Any thinking person can apprehend the purpose of the commandments, and understand why they were given.
[7] What great nation as to have a God close by — i.e., One Who answers everything that they wisely request. Nor
[8] is there a great nation whose decrees and laws all appear as righteous to the unbiased mind as do Israel’s. It is called a great nation on account of its wise and God-fearing people

[9] Only watch yourself Even if you forget everything else, do not forget the day when you stood at Mount Sinai. the things which your eyes have seen (as in, “all the people saw the thunder…” [Exodus 20:15])
[10] as long as they live upon the land GOD knew that they cannot perform the commandments properly if they are under foreign rule.
[11] the heart of heaven i.e., the center of heaven (from the standpoint of each viewer), as in “the heart of the sea” [Exodus 15:8]
[12] you saw no image, only a voice i.e., you heard a voice. The voice was not seen (I have already explained the passage “And all the people saw the thunder…” [Exodus 20:15])
[14] GOD instructed me GOD taught Moshe on Sinai all the statutes and ordinances; but Moshe did not tell them to Israel until the second year, and again in the fortieth year.
[15] Since you did not see any image,

[16] be careful not to ruin:
that which you have seen — i.e., the truth
or
your lives
a graven image something that is cut (as in, “Shlomo’s builders hewed” [I Kings 5:32]) male or female denotes the worship of particular idols. In addition, there are nations who daily fall down and worship the first animal that crosses their path. Others claim to invoke celestial powers through the image of a scorpion, for example, for its sting (or any of the forty-seven other constellations).

[19] the sun or the moon which are the great lights [Genesis 1:16]. After mentioning the stars, Scripture proceeds to give the general term all the heavenly bodies: the planets (which are luminous like stars), the constellations, and their shapes. be drawn away [Hebrew: niddaḥta] like a man who slips [Hebrew: yiddḥeh] and falls. allotted It is well-proven that every nation has a designated star. Every city, also, has its star. GOD has granted Israel great stature, in that GOD is their Advocate: they have no star, for they are the “inheritance of GOD” [II Samuel 20:19].
[20] He brought you out to be for Him a chosen people in the land wherein you will serve Him;
[21] however, GOD was angry with me, and I shall not see this benevolence. because of your words You brought about my exclusion from the land (as I have explained [comment on Numbers 20:8])

[23] any image i.e., an image of anything which GOD your God has commanded you i.e., as He has commanded you (or, which He commanded you not to do — as in, “I will command the clouds” [Isaiah 5:6]).1 This prohibition has already been mentioned; but Moshe repeats it here (including it among the commandments “which I instruct you” [:40]) in order to add that God is
[24] a consuming fire i.e., like a consuming fire (even though the phrase lacks a kaf). jealous of idolatry. His jealousy consumes like a fire, which spares neither root nor branch.
[25] After describing God as a “jealous God” [:24] Scripture now explains what will happen to them if they make idols or do evil concerning any of the other commandments, like murder or adultery.

[26] I call as witnesses Some say [Sa‘adya Gaon on 32:1] that the testimony of heaven and earth denotes the angels and the human race, respectively. Others say it alludes to the rains, as in, “I will make your skies like iron and your land like brass” [Leviticus 29:19]. In my opinion, heaven and earth are called as witnesses to watch them and their children forever, because they are permanent (as in “as long as the heaven endures on the earth” [11:21]; “Hear, O mountains, GOD’s controversy” [Micah 6:2]; and “this stone shall be a witness to us” [Joshua 24:27]). Those people who object to this interpretation on the grounds of such verses as “heaven shall vanish away like smoke…” [Isaiah 51:6] are vigilant in disputation, but their minds are asleep! you shall perish This word, like “do not learn” [Jeremiah 10:2], is vocalized with a long vowel because it ends a phrase.
[27] a minority explained above [comment on Genesis 34:30]

[28] neither see, nor hear… Scripture mentions four senses, and omits the fifth, because it is less refined than the others. The sense of touch also differs from the others, by being coextensive with all living tissue.

[29] Don’t be puzzled at the contrast in number between you [plural] will seek and you [singular] will find. First the verse addresses a group, and then it addresses the nation as a unit, or each individual. with all your heart explained below [comment on 30:10]
[31] abandon you i.e., weaken you

[32] study the history of ancient times study it now since the day The lamed is extraneous (as in many other Hebrew words), or it serves as a stylistic embellishment. from one end of heaven alludes to the horizon, as I have explained [comment on Genesis 1:6] whether there has been in his life-time
[33] Did ever a people hear This is a continuation of the previous verse, i.e., that which has never been heard

[34] has God ever attempted Some people have claimed — perish, perish the thought! — that the word “God” is meant here in a secular sense (i.e., “have gods ever attempted…”). attempted an anthropomorphism, to aid the listeners’ understanding miracles either this word is a general category, followed by specifics, or it is a qualifier, modifying the words that follow (i.e., “miraculous signs”). signs as in “performed the signs in the presence of the people” [Exodus 4:30] wonders the Ten Plagues, as it is written: “Moshe and Aaron performed all these wonders” [Exodus 11:10] war denotes in all likelihood the killing of the firstborn, and the judgment rendered against the idols [comment on Exodus 12:12] by mighty power Israel left Egypt mighty and irresistible, on account of the pillar of fire and the pillar of cloud. great terror denotes the drowning of Pharaoh and his army, together with the splitting of the sea before Israel against Egypt i.e., against the Egyptians

[35] God has shown you all these things, so that you shall know that He alone is God. You have been shown a verb in the passive, hof‘al form. I have already explained the word God [comment on Genesis 1:1].1 This word denotes a mysterious and profound concept. There is none other As I alluded to in my comment on the verse “there are yet higher ones over them” [Ecclesiastes 5:7] [in the cited comment, ibn Ezra indicates that there is a hierarchy of celestial powers, but that God is the supreme ruler over them all — Translator].

[36] to discipline you It is for this reason that he made you hear his voice: so that you would revere Him (as it is written: “let God not speak to us, lest we die” [Exodus 20:16]). What you saw frightened you; what you heard frightened you; but He continued to speak after making you hear his voice because

[37] he loved your fathers: Abraham, Yiṣḥaq, and Ya⊂aqov. his descendants an allusion to Ya⊂aqov. To say “their descendants” would include eight other nations with us! in His face This Hebrew metaphor denotes the anger He displayed toward Egypt. Some people translate it in the sense of “the angel of his presence saved them” [Isaiah 63:9]; but, in my opinion, it resembles “that you go to battle in person” [II Samuel 17:11].

[38] this day This phrase can denote the future, if it is taken to mean, “close to this day”. Actually, though, it refers to the conquest of the two Amorite kingdoms. Reuven, Gad, and half of Menasheh can certainly be called “Israel”, just as Scripture states elsewhere: “as Israel did to the land of his inheritance” [2:12]1

[39] After having said that “GOD is God; there is none beside Him” [:35], Scripture proceeds to elaborate why He must be honored. The evidence of one’s own eyes forms the premise of the argument. Any clear-headed, unbiased person must realize from the evidence that GOD alone is God: in heaven above (i.e., above man) and upon the earth beneath (i.e., beneath man. Man is the standard of comparison, as in “The skies above you will be like brass…” [28:23]). You, having seen all these wonders, having impressed it upon your hearts, must
[40] keep his commandments. Moreover, they are good for you, and for your children after you.
[41] At that time Moshe set aside… The day Moshe announced the Covenant coincided with the day he set aside these three cities.
[46] in the ravine of Mount ⊂Avarim. Although Mount ⊂Avarim is part of Mo⊃av, they arrived at Mount ⊂Avarim first, and then marched into the plains of Mo⊃av [Numbers 33:48].
[5:1] Moshe called out to all Israel to announce the terms of the covenant to the children (as I have explained).

[3] Not with our fathers i.e., not only with our fathers, as in “Your name will no longer be called ‘Ya⊂aqov’” [Genesis 35:10], but with us i.e., but also with us
or
GOD did not enter this covenant with our ancestors who were in Egypt, but, rather, with us. There were still many people in that camp who had heard the covenant spoken by GOD. That is why Moshe says, “we” — i.e., those who are still alive and with us now. The fact that Moshe uses the terms “to you” [:4] and “between you” [:6] is evidence for the correctness of this interpretation.
[4] face to face i.e., without an intermediary. When someone’s voice can be heard directly, it is called “face to face”, even if his face cannot be seen.

[5] I stood between GOD and you I have already explained this. Most likely, I stood between GOD… applies after the gathering at Sinai. At Sinai, He spoke to you face to face; but from that day onward, I stood between GOD and you, because you were afraid, as shall be explained. you were afraid of the fire even though you did not ascend the mountain as I advocated, but “Moshe [alone] approached the dense cloud” [Exodus 20:18]. The word saying: refers back to “GOD spoke to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire” [:4]. Although it is far removed from its antecedent, many Hebrew sentences exhibit the same construction: the interpolated verse is not a part of the quote.

[6] Do not be distressed that the wording is variant. Words are like bodies, whereas meanings are like souls. One can fashion two different utensils that perform the identical function. For example, “fraudulent” [:17] is synonymous to “false” [Exodus 20:13] — for everything false is fraudulent. Moreover, “Remember” [Exodus 20:8] is similar to “Keep” [:12], as I have already explained.
[12] Moshe added the words as GOD your God has commanded you, referring to the assembly at Mount Sinai.

[14] nor your ox, nor your donkey, nor any of your livestock a specification followed by a generalization. In the original [Exodus 20:10] only the generalization appears; but both passages mean the same thing. so that [even your slaves] shall rest Scripture proceeds to explain why your man-servant and your maid-servant are mentioned:

[15] For you must remember that you were a slave and you must consequently allow your own slave to rest therefore GOD your God has commanded you to observe this (allowing one’s slaves to rest) on the Sabbath day. In other words: GOD brought you out of slavery, and has ordered you to rest so that you shall remember that you were once a slave (according to some, the slaves themselves are not required to rest).

[16] has commanded you see my explanation above [comment on Exodus 20:1] that it may go well with you Some say this is an allusion to the World to Come. I shall reveal part of the mystery of the World to Come in my comment on “I kill, and I bring to life” [32:39]. your days is the antecedent of the clause, i.e., that which will go well with you.

[18] The Hebrew word ḥ-m-d has two different meanings. One meaning is robbery, oppression, taking from others through force or compulsion (as in, “no man will attack your land” [Exodus 34:24] — for if the verb denotes jealousy, then a verse intending to extol the land instead deprecates it!). The other meaning is jealousy, that does not express itself in overt action. All the scholars of antiquity believed that the First Commandment is “I am…” [:6] (even though it raises the question, why would one utter two commandments directly, and then stop?). I have already offered an explanation of the Ten Commandments that conforms to their belief. In my opinion, though, “I am…” is not one of the Ten Commandments. Rather, it introduces the Commander, and provides a basis for all the other Commandments, as I have already explained. “You shall not be jealous of your fellow-man’s house” [Exodus 20:14] is the Ninth Commandment, and “you shall not be jealous of your fellow-man’s wife” [Exodus 20:14] is the Tenth Commandment. Either “your fellow-man’s house” is part of the same Commandment as “your fellow-man’s wife”, or it is a separate principle in its own right. Here there is evidence for the latter: Moshe, explaining the Torah, in this book has replaced one instance of “you shall not be jealous” with “you shall not desire”. Many people have said that there is no sin in thinking something, and that thoughts carry neither reward nor punishment. I shall not go into the many proofs to the contrary at great length. Suffice to point out “The thoughts of the wicked are an abomination to GOD” [Proverbs 15:26], “You did well, insofar as it was your intention” [I Kings 8:18], and “to those who are upright in their hearts” [Psalms 125:4]. Moshe himself summed it all up when he said “to do it with your mouth and with your heart” [30:14]. The core of all the commandments is the improvement of character — and the majority of them are essentially reminders [see comment on Leviticus 19:19]. Moreover, the existence of a distinction between an intentional sin and an accidental sin is definitive proof.

[19] These words i.e., the Ten Commandments — but not the exact wording given above [comment on :5] a mighty voice the like of which they had never heard before that has not continued for this was the only revelation
[20] This verse explains why the people dispersed.

[21] His glory the display of fire His magnificence the thunder and lightning and sound of the shofar His voice the Ten Commandments (there is a single opinion that only the First Commandment was directly uttered by God)

[23] the voice of the living [plural] God Here the plural is used, as I have explained [comment on Genesis 1:1]. The word living in my opinion here designates the manifestation of God in Nature, as opposed to God Himself, Who does not move or change.
[24] then you [feminine] will communicate to us Use of the feminine pronoun also occurs in “But if You [feminine] deal thus with me” [Numbers 11:15], where its appearance is explained in detail.
[25] has been agreeable an ‘ayin-vav verb in the past tense

[26] Who would grant! Scripture does not say, “who would grant me”, but rather, “who would grant them” (the word them is displaced in the sentence, and appears after that they had such a will). Know that the Divine decree underlies all actions and all phenomena, in the sense that the nature and potentiality of everything in the universe, including living creatures, is determined by the action of the constellations on the four elements. A creature’s behavior at every moment is governed by its nature and its potential. However, as the author of the Sefer Yəṣira has explained, a certain amount of deviation can exist. Individuals derive their nature from the species, and they can change their nature within the boundaries of their species’s potential. This is the meaning of “GOD hardened the heart of Pharaoh” [Exodus 9:12], although elsewhere Scripture asserts, “he hardened his heart; he and his officials” [Exodus 9:34]. Both statements are true. Accordingly the prophets have said, “I know, GOD, that the way of a man is not in himself” [Jeremiah 10:23] and “Why have you made us stray, GOD, from Your ways?” [Isaiah 63:17]. Nevertheless, Moshe said, “choose life” [30:19]. GOD does not prevent anyone from achieving good. Indeed, He wishes to bestow good; and Scripture says so anthropomorphically by using the expression, Who would grant.
[27] Go, tell them implying that he descend from the mountain

[28] But you stay here with Me implying that he then re-ascend the mountain, as it is written: and I will speak to you all the commandments, the decrees, and the judgments. Thus, most of the Torah was told to Moshe on Mount Sinai. However, Moshe apparently transmitted it during the entirety of their stay in the Sinai Desert, as well as during the eleven days’ trip from Sinai.
[29] Now observe to practice The purpose of this seemingly redundant verse is to add the injunction do not turn aside to the right or the left.
[30] all of the path This metaphor explains the abovementioned “to the right or to the left” [:29] and it denotes
[6:1] the instructions, the decrees, and the judgments — the ultimate purpose of which is

[2] that you will revere — i.e., you, your son, and your grandson. Thus, the ultimate purpose of all the commandments is sincere faith. Faith is the fulfillment of man, and it is for faith that man was created, as it is written in Ecclesiastes [Ecclesiastes 12:13]. Faith will also assure long life — long life for the nation in the land of Israel, and long life for the individual in the World to Come.

[3] observe to practice I command you to observe that which is for your own benefit. a land flowing with milk… either
this is the displaced object of the verb “to inherit” [:1]
or
the verse omits a preposition, and should read “in a land flowing with milk…”. See “in the house of God” [II Kings 12:11] for a similar construction.

[4] Everything that our ancestors, of blessed memory, have transmitted concerning the reading of the Shma‘ is true and needs no justification. Know that the glorious Name is God’s proper name [comment on Exodus 3:15]. If so, why is it immediately followed by another name of God? The answer is that the Name can serve both as a proper name, and elsewhere as a descriptive, but not a proper name (just as “man” [Hebrew: ⊃adam] is both a proper name [Genesis 3:17], and a descriptive name derived from “Earth” [Hebrew: ⊃adama]). The evidence for this is that there are places where the Name appears in the construct case (as in “the Lord of Hosts” [I Samuel 1:11]) and other places where it stands alone. The Name is then further repeated, to say: God, who is our Lord, is one God — in other words, He is absolutely unique. An uncountable number of things demonstrate GOD’s uniqueness.1

[5] you shall love Since we have no gods other than He Himself, consequently you must love Him, there being no other god to love. with all your heart The “heart” denotes consciousness (and is here an allusion to the spirit of intelligence, corresponding to the first Divine Wheel [Ezekiel 1:15]), as in “wise of heart” [Exodus 31:6] and “acquires a heart” [Proverbs 15:32]. with all your soul denotes the corporeal spirit (i.e., desire). This force manifests itself in the kidneys. with all your might [Hebrew: m’odekha] from “much” [Hebrew: m’od] — in other words, to love Him exceedingly much — as much as you can — and that your love be unqualified.

[6] these words The Dissenters [this term, which appears fifteen times in ibn Ezra’s commentary on Deuteronomy, is used by ibn Ezra to denote anyone who does not accept the Rabbinic tradition, in full or in part; in ibn Ezra’s time the dominant non-Rabbinic movement was the Karaites, but a “Dissenter” is anyone who questions the Rabbinic tradition: frequently, but not necessarily, a Karaite — Translator] have applied this phrase to the Ten Commandments (they also believe the Ten Commandments are meant below in “you shall write them on the doorposts of your houses” [:9]); but the truth is that these words denotes all the commandments.

[7] repeat them over from “a sharp arrow” [Proverbs 25:18] — and it is well known that an arrow becomes sharp only after continuous, repeated sharpening. From this we see that the essence of Man is the service of GOD; and that one serves GOD by recognizing His works. The Exegetes, upon whom we all rely, have transmitted to us the prescribed times for the reading of the Shma‘: when you sit (this adverbial phrase modifies speak of them) when you lie down to sleep (for no commandments apply to someone who is actually sleeping). Thus we see that speak of them includes both speech and thought.

[8] Bind them as a sign upon your arm literally. frontlets [Hebrew: ṭoṭafot] Scripture contains no related words. Although the Dissenters have said the word comes from “preach” [Ezekiel 21:2], this is unlikely, since the triliteral root of “preach” is n-ṭ-f, while this word is missing the nun and has two ṭet’s.

[9] You shall write them The Dissenters have also disputed this commandment, claiming that it is figurative, as in “bind them about your neck” [Proverbs 3:3]; but we who have received the truth from our ancestors shall disregard these fabricators.
[11] good vocalized with a shuruq instead of a ḥolem: The two vowels interchange when the word is not in the construct case.
[12] the house of bondage There, your cities and houses were not so well-stocked.

[13] Revere i.e., do not do anything forbidden serve i.e., perform the positive commandments swear by His name and not in the name of any other gods (compare, “every tongue shall swear” [Isaiah 45:23]). In other words, you shall not swear in the name of any god, other than GOD alone. But you may swear to affirm testimony, or to confirm a contract — so long as it is true.
[14] Do not follow other gods since you may not swear in their name.

[16] in Massah the name of a place1, as in “He called the name of the place Massah…” [Exodus 17:7]. There I explained the meaning of the name [comment on Exodus 17:2]. People were questioning whether “GOD is among us” [Exodus 17:7]: If so, we will worship him. But there is no need to put GOD to the test. Simply
[17] keep his commandments; and
[18] if you do what is right in His sight, He will grant you every good, and
[19] He will thrust out all your enemies (the heh in to thrust out is part of the triliteral root of the word — compare, “he pushed him down” [Numbers 35:22]).
[20] what are the rituals That is to say: Why do we, intelligent human beings, accept such shackles?
[21] You shall answer that GOD redeemed us from the house of slavery,
[23] and He has performed all this good for us; consequently we are obliged

[24] to revere His name, having already acknowledged that He has been our Benefactor. Moreover, it will be to our benefit, and it will keep us alive — for His commandments are life to those who find them.

[25] It will be our privilege Some say that this alludes to reward in the World to Come. Literally, though, it means that from the standpoint of strict justice, we are obliged to obey His will, because He is our Master. In my opinion the verse carries an additional meaning: All the nations will perceive that we are righteous, because we follow commandments and laws which are themselves righteous (for so it is written [4:8]).
[7:1] fell from, “your olives will drop off” [28:40] (the nun here is part of the triliteral root).

[4] will turn your son away
The subject of the sentence is “his son” mentioned above [:3] — his son to whom you should not give your daughter in marriage
or
The subject of the sentence is your foreign neighbor, whose daughter you should not take for your son in marriage, as mentioned above
[5] But thus i.e., Only this shall you do to them —

[6] because you are holy people — and you shall not make yourself loathsome through the objects of the Gentiles, who adorn themselves with monuments and with Ashera trees. beloved As explained above [comment on Exodus 19:5], this word denotes something beautiful, the like of which can be found nowhere else (as in “the treasures of kings” [Ecclesiastes 2:8]).
[7] attach you and choose you and no one else.
[8] His keeping a verbal noun

[9] He is the Almighty He is truly the Almighty, because He is both powerful and faithful. This point is made in reference to “the oath” [:8]; for one can be faithful, but powerless to fulfill one’s oath, just as one can be powerful, yet faithless.
He keeps the covenant, and the kindness, for His beloved No one has higher stature than they and for them who keep His commandments they are second in stature
or
He keeps the covenant, and the kindness, for them who love Him in their hearts …them who keep His commandments in their speech and in their actions
a thousand generations “Thousand” here denotes “infinite”. Some people have incorrectly seen here an allusion to the theory that the planetary cycles repeat themselves every thirty-six thousand years. In fact, they repeat themselves approximately every seventy years.
