[10] He repays His enemies [plural] every one of his enemies (as in, “the righteous [plural] are secure [singular] like a lion” [Proverbs 28:1] [cf. comment on Leviticus 19:8]) to his face i.e., to himself, personally. Some people also compare the word to “in His face”, a Hebrew metaphor for “in His anger” [cf. comment on Leviticus 26:17], meaning that He will punish His enemies for having made themselves enemies of the Truth. to destroy him; for his enemy He does not defer Some interpret the verse to mean that the wicked are rewarded in this world for the good they have done, and He does not defer their reward for the World to Come. In my opinion, though, the correct interpretation contrasts the wicked against the righteous. Unlike them, who endure “a thousand generations” [:9], GOD’s enemies will perish, and will not continue into the future, although they may falsely expect their children or their grandchildren to survive (see “to the third and fourth generation” [Exodus 20:5]).
[11] Therefore keep Just as GOD keeps the covenant, so must you keep His commandments.
1Some people see an allusion in this verse to the commandment of studying the appearance of the stars — but, in my opinion, this is far-fetched.

1The parasha of Yitro contains “God spoke…” [Exodus 20:1] as well as “the God answered him vocally” [Exodus 19:19]. In the latter passage Scripture explicitly uses the definite article, because speech everywhere is a manifestation of the Divine. Without a definite article, someone might misinterpret the word to denote Godliness, rather than God who is the source of Godliness.

1 This passage does not denote the future, as many have interpreted it. Witness the phrase “To him who smote great kings” [Psalms 136:17]. Although the Psalmist has mentioned Siḥon and ‘Og only, he says, “a heritage to Israel his servant” [Psalms 136:22].

1The verse that says, “on that day GOD will be one, and His name one” [Zechariah 14:15] speaks only of mankind’s knowledge of GOD. Moreover, in my opinion this verse refers to the acceptance of GOD as king. The passage is best translated: “GOD will be the king of the whole Earth. On that day GOD will be the only [king], with a single name.” Compare, “then I will convert the nations to a purer language” [Zephaniah 2:9]. When the entire world will speak a single language, then GOD will have a single name.
1despite the fact that Scripture uses the definite article. Compare “Zevaḥ and Ṣalmunna⊂ were in [the] Qarqor” [Judges 8:10] and “mustered them in [the] Ṭla⊃im” [I Samuel 15:4].

chapter.title: ⊂Eqev
chapter.p: [12]If you follow these rules, keep and practice them, GOD your God will consequently keep with you the merciful covenant which He affirmed to your forefathers. [13]He will love you, bless you, and increase you. He will bless the fruit of your belly and the produce of your land: your grain and your wine, your oil, the herds of your cattle, and the litters of your sheep in the land which He swore to your forefathers to give you. [14]You will be blessed above all peoples; there will be no sterile male nor sterile female among you, or among your livestock. [15]GOD will remove from you any sickness; He will put upon you none of the evil diseases of Egypt which you have known, but will inflict them upon all your enemies. [16]You will consume all the nations which GOD your God gives you; your eye shall have no pity. You shall not serve their gods, for it would be a snare to you.

[17] You may perhaps think to yourselves: ‘These nations are too many for me; how can I dispossess them?’ [18]You must not be afraid of them. Remember well what GOD your God did to Pharaoh, and to all Egypt, [19]and the great miracles which your eyes have witnessed, and the signs, and the wonders, and the mighty force, and the outstretched arm, whereby GOD your God brought you out; so will GOD your God do to all the nations whom you fear. [20]GOD your God, will also send the ṣir⊂ah against them, so that the remainder who hide themselves from you will perish. [21]You must not be terrified by them, for GOD your God in your midst is a great and awe-inspiring God. [22]GOD your God will cast down these nations little by little; you cannot destroy them at one time, lest the wild beasts become numerous against you. [23]GOD your God will deliver them up before you, and will rout them in a crushing defeat, until they be annihilated. [24]He will deliver their kings in your hand, and you will obliterate their name from under heaven; no one will stand up against you until your annihilating of them. [25]You shall burn the statues of their gods in fire. The graven images of their idols will you burn in fire. You shall not desire silver and gold on them, and take for yourself, lest you be ensnared by it; for it is abhorrent to GOD your God. [26]You must not bring abominations into your house, that you be banned like them; you must utterly detest them, and utterly abhor them; for they are under the ban.

[8:1]You shall observe to practice every commandment which I instruct you today, that you may live, and multiply, and come and possess the land which GOD affirmed to your forefathers. [2]Remember all the path which GOD your God has led you in the wilderness these forty years, sending hardships to you in order to test you, to know what was in your heart, and whether you would observe His commandments, or not. [3]He afflicted you, and He famished you, and fed you with manna, a food which neither you, nor your forefathers knew, in order to inform you that man does not live by the bread alone, but man lives on everything that emanates from the mouth of GOD. [4]Your clothes upon your bodies did not wear out nor did your foot swell these forty years. [5]You will know with your heart that as a man disciplines his son through hardships so did GOD your God discipline you. [6]You shall therefore observe the commandments of GOD your God: follow in His way and revere Him. [7]For GOD your God is bringing you into a land of plenty, a land of brooks of water, of fountains and underground wells, springing forth from valleys and hills; [8]a land of wheat and barley, of vines, fig trees, and pomegranates; a land of oil-rich olives and honey. [9]a land wherein you will eat bread without indigence for you will lack nothing in it; a land whose stones contain iron, and from whose hills you can dig copper. [10]When you have eaten and are satisfied, give thanks to GOD your God for the good land which He has given you. [11] Beware lest you forget GOD your God, by not keeping His commandments, His rules, and His decrees which I instruct you today. [12]Lest you eat your fill, and build comfortable homes and dwell therein, [13]and your herds and flocks multiply, and your gold and silver be increased and all that you have become numerous; [14]and you become haughty and forget GOD your God Who brought you forth from the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery; [15]Who led you through the vast and dreadful wilderness, fiery serpents and scorpions, a dry land with no water in it, Who brought forth for you water from a rock of flint; [16]Who fed you in the wilderness with manna which your fathers had not known, in order to test you by affliction, so that it might be well with you in the end, [17]and you say to yourselves: ‘My strength and the might of my own hand gathered for me all this power,’ [18]Remember GOD your God, for it is He Who gives you strength to accumulate wealth, that He may fulfill His covenant which He affirmed to your forefathers, as it is today.

[19]If you forget GOD your God, and follow other gods, serve them and worship them — I attest to you today that you will surely perish; [20]like the nations that GOD will destroy before you, so will you be destroyed, consequent to your not accepting the words of GOD your God.

[9:1]Hear, O Israel: you cross the Jordan today, entering to dispossess greater and mightier nations than you are, great cities fortified up to the sky; [2]great and tall people, the descendants of the Anakim, of whom you have known and of whom you have heard said: ‘Who can stand up against the descendants of Anok?’ [3]Know then this day that it is GOD your God, it is He who goes before you as a devouring fire. He will destroy them and he will subdue them before you, that you drive them out and destroy them quickly, as GOD has promised you. [4]And when GOD your God has thrust them from before you, do not say to yourselves: ‘GOD has brought me to this land because of my meritorious deeds, and He has driven them out because of the wickedness of these nations.’ [5]You do not come to possess their land for your meritorious deeds or for your uprightness. It is rather because of the wickedness of these nations that GOD your God drives them out from before you, and to fulfill the promise that GOD made to your forefathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. [6]Recognize the fact that it is not because of your merit that GOD your God has given you this good land to possess, for you are a stiff-necked people. Though you are a disobedient people, yet He will not annul the promise made to your forefathers. [7]Remember, do not forget, how you have provoked GOD your God in the wilderness; from the day you left the land of Egypt, until you came to this place, you have been rebellious against GOD. [8]Even in Ḥorev you provoked GOD, and GOD was angered with you to the point of destroying you. [9]When I went up into the mount to take the tablets of stone — the Tablets of the Covenant which GOD enacted with you — and I tarried on the mount forty days and forty nights; neither did I eat bread, nor did I drink water.

[10]And GOD gave me the two tablets of stone, written with the finger of God. They contained all the words, which GOD had spoken to you on the mount from amidst the fire on the day of the Assembly. [11]It was at the mark of forty days and forty nights that GOD gave me the two tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant. [12]And GOD said to me: Arise, descend quickly from here, for your people, whom you have brought forth from Egypt, have corrupted; they have quickly turned away from the way which I commanded them; they have made themselves a molten image.’ [13]GOD said to me further, ‘I see that this nation is a stiff-necked people. [14]Leave Me alone, and I shall destroy them and blot out their name from under heaven, and I will make of you a mightier and greater nation then they are.’ [15]I turned and came down the mount, as the mount was burning with fire. I held the two tablets of the covenant in my two hands. [16]I saw how you had sinned against GOD your God: you had made yourselves a molten calf; you had turned away quickly from the way which GOD had commanded you. [17]So I seized the two tablets, and cast them out of my two hands, breaking them in pieces before your eyes. [18]I prostrated myself before GOD as before, forty days and forty nights; I ate no bread, nor did I drink water, for all your sins which you had committed, in acting badly before GOD, provoking Him. [19]For I dreaded the anger and the fury which GOD raged against you to destroy you. And GOD listened to me that time as well. [20]GOD also raged against Aaron, to have him destroyed, so I also prayed for the sake of Aaron at that time. [21]I took your sin — the calf which you had made — and burned it in fire, and crushed it, pounding it very small, until it was reduced to thin powder; then I cast its dust into the brook that descended from the mountain. [22](You also provoked GOD at Tav‘erah, at Massah, and at Graves-of-Lust. [23]And when GOD sent you from Qadesh-Barnea, saying: ‘Go up and possess the land which I am giving you,’ you rebelled against the message of GOD; neither did you trust Him, nor have you listened to His voice. [24]You have been rebellious against GOD since the day I have known you.) [25]When I prostrated myself before GOD — those forty days and forty nights that I was prostrated — for GOD threatened to destroy you, [26]I prayed to GOD, as follows: ‘O Lord GOD, do not wipe out Your people, and Your inheritance, whom You have redeemed through Your greatness and whom You have brought out from Egypt with mighty power. [27]Remember Your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, turn not to the stubbornness of this people, its wickedness, and its sinfulness, [28]lest the inhabitants of the land from which You have brought us out will say: “It was because GOD was not able to bring them into the land which He promised them, and because He hated them, that He brought them out to slay them in the wilderness.” [29]Yet they are Your people and Your inheritance, whom You brought out by Your great power and by Your outstretched arm.’

[10:1]At that time, GOD said to me: ‘Hew two tablets of stone like the first, and ascend to Me on the mount; and make for you a wooden ark. [2]I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets which you smashed, and you will put them in the ark.’ [3]So I made an ark of accacia wood, hewed two tablets of stone like the former ones, and I ascended the mount holding the two tablets in my hand. [4]And He wrote on the tablets, according to the first writing — the Ten Pronouncements which GOD spoke to you, on the mount from the midst of the fire, on the day of the Assembly, and GOD gave them to me. [5]When I turned and descended the mount, I put the tablets into the ark that I had made, and they remained there, as GOD had commanded me. [6](The Children of Israel traveled from Beeroth-Benejakon to Moserah. There Aaron died, and there he was buried; so Eleazar ministered in his place as kohen. [7]From there they marched to Gudgod, and from Gudgod to Yotvah, an area rich in brooks of water.) [8]At that time, GOD set apart the tribe of Levi, to carry the Ark of the covenant of GOD, to stand before GOD to minister before Him, and to bless the community in His name, even to this day. [9]Therefore the Levites have no part and no allotment with their brethren. GOD is their allotment, as GOD your God has spoken concerning them. [10]I stayed on the mount, as the first days: forty days and forty nights; and GOD listened to me once again; GOD consented not to destroy you. [11]And GOD said to me: ‘Arise, lead the march of the people, let them enter and possess the land which I promised to their forefathers to give them.’

[12]And now, O Israel, what does GOD your God require of you? It is to revere GOD your God, to follow in all His ways, to love him, and to serve GOD your God with all your heart and with all your soul, [13]to keep the commandments of GOD, and His decrees which I instruct you today for your own benefit. [14]Mark! To GOD your God belong the heaven and the heaven’s heavens, the earth and all that is in it. [15]It is only because of your forefathers, whom GOD desired and loved, that today He has chosen their descendants after them, you, from among all the nations. [16]Circumsize the foreskin of your heart, and do not stiffen your neck any longer. [17]For GOD your God is the Supreme Judge, Lord of all lords; the great, mighty, and awesome God, Who is never partial and is never appeased by bribery, [18]He executes justice for the orphan and the widow, and loves the alien, providing him with bread and raiment. [19]Love therefore the alien; for you were aliens in the land of Egypt. [20]Revere GOD your God; Him shall you serve, and to Him will you cleave, and by His Name you will swear. [21]He is your glory and He is your God, Who has done for you these great and awesome things which you have witnessed with your own eyes. [22]Your forefathers went down to Egypt seventy souls only, and now GOD your God has made you as numerous as the stars in heaven. [11:1]Love, therefore, GOD your God, keep His observances, His decrees, His rules and His commandments — always. [2]Take note today, that it is not your children — who have not known and who have not witnessed the discipline of GOD your God, His greatness, His mighty force, and His outstretched arms, [3]His signs, His actions which He performed in the midst of Egypt, against Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and all his land; [4]what He did to the Egyptian army, its horses, and chariots; how He made the waters of the Red Sea flow over them as they pursued you, and how GOD destroyed them to this day; [5]what He had performed for you in the wilderness, until you came to this place; [6]and how He treated Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab, of the tribe of Reuben; how the earth opened her mouth, and swallowed them up, with their households, their tents, and all the possessions which were on their feet, from the midst of all Israel. — [7]but your own eyes have seen all the great work of GOD that He performed. [8]Keep, therefore, all the commandments which I instruct you today, that you may be strong, and you will come and occupy the land which you are about to cross into, to occupy it; [9]and that you may live long in the land which GOD promised to your forefathers to give to them and to their descendants, a land flowing with milk and honey.

[10]For the land which you enter to possess is not like the land of Egypt out from which you came, which, when you planted your seeds, you could water by foot like a vegetable garden. [11]But the land into which you cross to possess, is a land of hills and valleys which requires rain from heaven for its water; [12]a land which GOD your God examines: the eyes of GOD your God are constantly on it, from the beginning of the year to the end of the year.

[13]If you will carefully follow my instructions which I instruct you today, to love GOD your God, and serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul; [14]then I will give the rain for your land in its season; the early rain and the latter rain, that you may gather in your grain, your wine and your oil. [15]And I will provide grass in your fields for your cattle; you will eat and be satisfied. [16]Take good care, lest your heart entice you, and you stray, and serve other gods, and worship them. [17]For the anger of GOD will burn against you, and He will close up the heaven so that there will be no rain, and the ground will not yield its produce; and you will be quickly lost from upon the good land which GOD is giving you. [18]Place these words in your hearts and souls; bind them for a sign upon your arm, and let them be frontlets between your eyes. [19]Teach them to your children that they may speak of them when you sit in your house, and when you travel on the road, when you lie down, and when you rise up. [20]Write them on the door posts of your houses and on your gates. [21]So that your days, and the days of your children, may be extended in the land which GOD promised to your fathers to give to them, as long as the heaven endures on the earth.
chapter.ftnote: [12] consequently i.e., the end reward — as in, “always, to the end” [Psalms 119:112]. ¶ The meaning of the earlier passage “He keeps the covenant” [:9] is that he kept the covenant of Abraham; but if you are among “those that love him” [:9], then He will continue to keep the covenant. If you are one of “those who love him”, then

[13] He will love you, and bless you, and increase you (this being the meaning of “the covenant and the kindness” [:9]). your belly denotes progeny (“belly” is a euphemism). Scripture lists grain, wine, and oil, because they are the main produce of your land. I have already explained the word “herd” [Exodus 13:12] [the reference is to an earlier commentary on Exodus, known as the Perush Haqqaṣar — Translator]. your cattle [Hebrew: כalafekha] as in “our oxen [Hebrew: כallufeynu] are heavy laden” [Psalms 144:14]. litters that is, “flocks”. A great Spanish commentator [this is believed to be Yәhudah HaLevy — Translator] revealed the reason why the Hebrews refer to cattle with the term “herd”, and to Caprinae with the term “litters” [Hebrew: ⊂ashtarot] — similar to his interpretation of “the Ba⊂alim and the ⊂Ashtarot” [Judges 10:10] to mean “the lord [Hebrew: ba⊂al] of the ascendent constellation [namely, Taurus the Bull — Translator], and the tenth [Hebrew: ⊂as̀iri] constellation [namely, Capricorn the Goat — Translator]”.

[14] Not only will He bless the fruit of your womb, but also there will not be among you any sterile male (one whose semen cannot induce conception), nor even any infertility among your livestock; moreover,
[15] you will not fall ill from any sickness (a well-known, conventional occurrence), nor from any diseases (which are unnatural).

[16] you will consume We are commanded to destroy them, like someone consuming bread, as evidenced by the subsequent phrase your eye shall have no pity. For it [singular] would be a snare to you i.e., every one of their gods.
[20] the ṣir⊂ah a bodily sickness, from ṣara⊂at [Leviticus 13:2].
[21] you shall not be terrified of them; rather, you should only be terrified of GOD, who is a great and awe-inspiring God.

[22] Sa‘adya Gaon says [Sa‘adya Gaon on this verse and on Exodus 23:29] that lest the wild beasts become numerous alludes to the sign which will indicate at what future time they should undertake to overpower their enemies; but there is no need for this interpretation, as I have explained [cf. comment on Exodus 23:29].

[24] Your annihilating is a verbal noun; even though the second syllable is vocalized with a ḥiriq, the phrase “leaving [Hebrew: hishכir] him a survivor” [Numbers 21:35] exhibits a (probably) similar construction. Conclusive evidence here is them, the direct object of the verb.

[25] silver and gold on them either
You shall not desire the silver and gold that is on them
or
You shall not accept silver and gold in exchange for leaving them alone.
The vav in the word ensnared [Hebrew: tivvaqesh] replaces a yod (which appears in the word “I have laid a snare [Hebrew: yaqoshti] for you” [Jeremiah 50:24]).
[8:1] every commandment That is to say: If you desire to observe the commandments — so that you may live — then
[2] remember the path. I have already explained the idea behind sending hardships to you in order to test you, to know… [comment on Genesis 22:1].

[3] He afflicted you on the road. He famished you before the coming of the manna.1 — or, more likely, He “famished” needs other than hunger. The word they knew [Hebrew: yad⊂un] ends with a nun, like “They poured out [Hebrew: ṣaqun] a silent prayer” [Isaiah 26:16], and also “they camped [Hebrew: yaḥanun] on the other side of כArnon” [Judges 11:18]. The word to inform you is in the infinitive form. the bread means that which a man is accustomed to. that emanates from the mouth of GOD i.e., what He decrees. Compare, “as the word went out of the king’s mouth” [Esther 7:8]. The sense of the verse is that Man does not live from just bread, but rather, from the energy that it contains — and could live just as well from energy that comes to us from Heaven, through the Divine decree (this is the meaning of emanates from the mouth of GOD). The proof is that although you did not eat bread, you nevertheless lived [cf. 29:5].

[4] Your clothes Some say that this was a miraculous sign. Others say that they brought many garments out of Egypt. The probable explanation is that a diet of manna naturally does not give rise to perspiration. did not swell [Hebrew: vaṣeqah] from “they baked the dough [Hebrew: baṣeq” [ Exodus 12:39]. When someone travels on foot for a long distance, his foot normally swells up. Here, it is likely either that GOD gave them extra endurance, or that He made them walk slowly.
[5] you will know with your heart You will have a heartfelt (i.e., a fundamental) understanding.
[6] Because you listen to the Lord when He disciplines you — even though He may discipline you by famishing you, or by afflicting you with thirst along the way —
[7] your reward shall be that He will bring you into the good land.
[8] a land of wheat… Scripture mentions the foods that are metabolized into blood. I have already explained honey [comment on Leviticus 2:11].
[9] indigence leanness, poverty (see also “a poor and wise child” [Ecclesiastes 4:13]).

[13] Contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Moshe ben Shmu’el Gikatilla HaKohen, the yod in multiply is in place of a heh [Gikatilla held that lamed-heh verbs are in fact quadriliteral, and that a penultimate yod forms part of the root — Translator].
[14] you become haughty and forget that you had been an abject slave,

[15] and forget the poverty and the hunger and the thirst that you suffered in the wilderness — and that, despite all this, GOD provided for you. The word in the wilderness modifies two different clauses, as if Scripture had said “through the vast” (that is, both long and wide) “and dreadful wilderness, a wilderness of fiery…”. flint denotes any hard stone.
[17] this power that is, riches (as in, “they shall leave their wealth [literally: their power] to others” [Psalms 49:11]), in the sense of: the fruits of their toil, and of their strength.
[18] Remember In other words: If it should occur to you to say, “My strength and the might of my hand…”, then remember Him Who gives you strength.
[20] consequent the ultimate reward (whether for good or for evil)
[9:1] you cross today I.e., during this season (or perhaps the sense of the verse is, “Think of yourself as if you were crossing today”).
[3] The metaphor a devouring fire connotes a rapid destruction. Thus, Scripture subsequently says quickly.
[7] The lamed in from the day is extraneous. in the wilderness after you departed from
[10] The word with the finger has already been explained [comment on Exodus 31:18].
[11] at the mark either the beginning or the end of the forty days [cf. comment on Numbers 13:25]. ¶ Scripture here reveals that on the very day when Moshe was given the tablets,
[12] the Golden Calf was made.
[18] I prostrated myself This is what was stated earlier, in the passage, “now I will go up to GOD” [Exodus 32:30] (the word I prostrated myself means that he bowed his face to the ground).

[19] that time as well Moshe had previously prayed for them 1) At the Reed Sea (this is evident from “Why are you crying out to me?” [Exodus 14:15]) 2) “He prayed to GOD and GOD showed him a tree” [Exodus 15:25]
[21] your sin denotes the calf, and Scripture proceeds to clarify that, by specifying the appositive the calf. crushed into fine dust, as the dust of the earth.

[22] Tav⊂erah is probably the name of a place where they encamped for only one day, therefore it is not mentioned in the parasha of Mas⊂ey; but it is one of the thirty places they traversed on the way from Mount Sinai to Graves-of-Lust, as I have explained [comment on Numbers 10:31]. The connection between Tav⊂erah and Massah is that in both places the people were grumbling against — were testing, as it were — GOD. The reason Tav⊂erah is mentioned first, before Massah, is that at Massah nothing happened to them.1 Some say that Tav⊂erah is Massah, along the lines of “from the top of S̀әnir and Ḥermon” [Songs of Songs 4:8]. But the correct explanation is the one I have given.
[23] you did not trust in your thoughts. you did not listen in your actions.
[25] Moshe returns
[26] to elaborate on the prayer that he prayed [cf. :18].

[29] Your people and Your inheritance because of their forefathers. The reason Scripture says they are Your people is that clearly they are the ones who are Your people, because they are the ones whom You brought out by Your great power which you revealed in the world.

[10:1] At that time during the abovementioned [9:25] forty days. a wooden ark The Exegetes, of blessed memory, have said [Palestinian Talmud Soṭa 8:3 (22b)] that Moshe himself made an original ark, different from the one that was later made. Their evidence is

[3] I made an ark, followed by I hewed…, after which Moshe says “I put the tablets into the ark which I had made” — and their understanding is greater than ours. ¶ But it would seem that “The glory of GOD dwelt” [Exodus 24:16] refers to the glory that the elders had already seen [Exodus 24:10]. The exact date of Moshe’s first ascent is not clear, and a surface reading of Scripture suggests that Moshe only fasted for eighty days: The period denoted by “I stayed on the mount, as the first days:” [:10] coincides with the second forty-day period [9:25], so that the sense of the passage is, When I had stayed in the mountain these forty days, GOD “hearkened” unto me [cf. :10], and said, “lead the march” [:11] — which is the same as “go, lead the people” [Exodus 32:34]. If all this be true, then the “wooden ark” [:1] was made at Moshe’s command, but it is actually the same ark that Bәṣalכel made [cf. Exodus 37:1]. I made an ark That is, he commanded that an ark be made. Consequently, “Moshe gathered” [Exodus 35:1] must mean, “Moshe had gathered” (I have already shown you many similar instances). ¶ All this was necessitated by the passage

[5] they remained there as GOD had commanded me, assuming that the reference is to “put the Testimony into the Ark” [Exodus 25:16]. Nevertheless, it is also possible that the reference is to “make for you a wooden ark” [:1]. In any case, the Tradition must prevail.

[6] The children of Israel traveled from Bәכerot-Bәné-Ya⊂ɐqan to Moserah. This verse is inserted here, because Moshe had said “I also prayed for the sake of Aaron at that time” [9:20]; Scripture accordingly informs us that Aaron did not die, until the fortieth year. The evidence for the correctness of this explanation is that, while they were at Mount Sinai, “at that time, GOD set apart the tribe of Levi” [:8] (as I have explained in my commentary on the parasha of Bәmidbar [comment on Numbers 3:1]). Our ancestors asserted [Palestinian Talmud Yoma 1:1 (38b)] that they backtracked to a previous encampment — but what then is to be done with the word “there” in there Aaron died, and there he was buried? The Spaniard Rabbi Isaac ben Yәhudah ibn Ghiyyat, of blessed memory, translated the word “there” into “then” (similarly, “from then on [literally: from there] he became a shepherd” [Genesis 49:24]). But in my opinion none of this is needed. Rather, Bәכerot-Bәné-Ya⊂ɐqan is not the same as “Bәné-Ya⊂ɐqan” [Numbers 33:31]; and also, Moserah is not the same as “Moserot” [Numbers 33:30]. Bәכerot-Bәné-Ya⊂ɐqan is another name for Qadesh, and Moserah is the name of the desert region surrounding Mount Hor. There are many similar instances (e.g., note that Scripture calls a place “the Shur Wilderness” [Exodus 15:22], but in another verse says “the כEytam Wilderness” [Numbers 33:8]).

[7] From there they marched to Gudgod This is not the same as “Ḥor-Haggidgad” [Numbers 33:32]. Rather, it is the general name for the region that includes Ṣalmonah [Numbers 23:41], Punon [Numbers 23:42], and also כOvot [Numbers 23:43]. Yoṭvata here is the place that is elsewhere called “Bәכer” (for so it is written: “from thence they went to Bәכer” [Numbers 21:16]), which explains the phrase an area rich in brooks of water. The nobles dug with their staves, and water flowed forth [cf. Numbers 21:18]. ¶ This verse, containing the statement from there they marched to Gudgod, is juxtaposed to “Eleazar ministered” [:6]. Even though I previously told you [comment on Exodus 29:42] that Israel offered no sacrifices after they left Mount Sinai, it seems likely that they did offer them when they arrived at Ṣalmonah and Punon. Thus the beginning of Eleazar’s ministry as High Priest occurred in those places, on Rosh HaShanah (he officiated in the place called Bәכer on Yom Kippur). The explanation, then, is as follows: “Eleazar officiated when they marched to such-and-such a place. And why was Eleazar the kohen? Because

[8] at the time of the worship of the Calf, GOD set apart the tribe of Levi, to carry the Ark, and to stand before GOD.” The Levites were to minister before Him together with the descendants of Aaron. to bless in His name for Eleazar used to give the Priestly Blessing [cf. Numbers 6:24ff.].
[9] GOD is their allotment along the lines of “GOD is the portion of my inheritance, and of my cup” [Psalms 16:5] — meaning, service of GOD through the study of His ways.
[10] I have already explained I stayed on the mount [comment on :1].
[11] The word lead the march is a verbal noun.
[15] He has chosen their descendants who are you — and the phrase is followed by the appositive you.

[16] Circumsize the foreskin of your hearts by distancing yourselves from desires, which are as thick and as heavy as a foreskin. Perhaps the idiom also means: Purify your heart, so that it will understand the truth. I have explained the word your neck [comment on Exodus 32:9]. Moreover, the idiom is used here, because he previously had said “you are a stiff-necked people” [9:6].

[17] I have already explained the phrase the Supreme Judge [comment on Genesis 1:1]. The Lord of lords for there are levels of greatness among rulers, as in “and there are yet higher ones over them” [Ecclesiastes 5:7]. One who recognizes these attributes is “circumsized of heart” [cf. :16].

[18] executes justice Although He is lofty, He executes justice for the orphan and widow, who have no ally. Compare [Megilla 31a], “Father of the fatherless” [Psalms 68:6]. Likewise with respect to the alien: He will provide for those who depend on Him. Since GOD loves the alien,
[19] you are required to love him.

[20] Revere GOD your God do not violate the negative commandments. Him shall you serve through the positive commandments. to Him will you cleave in your heart. by His Name you will swear in speech (in the manner prescribed [Temurah 3b]).
[21] He is your glory i.e., it is appropriate for you to glorify in Him, because He has done awesome things for you.
[22] I have already explained seventy souls [comment on Genesis 46:23]. Since He has multipled you,
[11:1] you are bound to love Him (which has been said before, but here Scripture adds always).

[2] it is not your children The conclusion of this sentence is “your own eyes have seen” [:7]. In other words: These miracles are not for the future, to be seen by your children; but rather, you yourselves have seen them. His greatness, His strong hand, His outstretched arm in taking you out of Egypt.
[3] His signs, His actions toward Pharaoh, who was the main recipient.

[4] made flow [Hebrew: heṣif] from “water flowed [Hebrew: ṣafu] over my head” [Lamentations 3:54]. destroyed them meaning that never again did their descendants arise to attain their level of grandeur.
[5] what He performed for you in the wilderness denotes the manna.

[6] their households specifically, their wives and children. all the possessions is a general term. on their feet meaning, which existed on their account — or, perhaps the term is to be taken literally.
[7] After having seen all of these things with your own eyes,
[8] take care to keep GOD’s commandments. you will occupy [Hebrew: viyrishtem] the resh is vocalized with a ḥiriq because the vav is vocalized with a ḥiriq [cf. comment on 4:1].
[10] For the land… After establishing that you are obliged to keep His commandments, the meaning of this passage is: For the land is not like the land of Egypt; rather,

[12] it has a need for GOD to set His eyes upon it all year long. (This latter expression is a figure of speech, connoting someone who watches for whatever is needed, and provides for everything in its proper time. The word from the beginning is missing an ’alef. Many similar words exist [cf. comment on Leviticus 11:43].) For this reason, Scripture says

[14] I will give the rain for your land — i.e., elaborating the abovementioned “the eyes of GOD your God are set upon it” [:12]. early rain [Hebrew: yoreh] The rain which notifies [Hebrew: yoreh] of a prosperous year, coming at the beginning of the season. The meaning of the word latter rain is known [e.g., Zechariah 10:1].
[15] you will eat and be satisfied referring to the abovementioned “grain and wine” [:14], not the more proximate grass in your fields.

[17] I have already explained the word its produce [comment on Leviticus 26:4]. you will be quickly lost You shall be exiled like wanderers because of the famine, even though the land had formerly been good. ¶ For this reason,
[18] you must take these matters to heart. The word frontlets has already been explained [comment on 6:8].
[21] If you take these matters to heart, you will not perish from upon the land; rather, you will extend your days as long as the heaven endures on the earth.
1Or, perhaps He famished you with the manna itself, insofar as it was extremely light food [cf. Numbers 21:5].

1 However, some say that ⊂Amaleq came because they had “tested” GOD; Moshe thus first recalls the burning of GOD’s fire against them, and then the ⊂Amalekite offensive, and then the smiting of the gluttons — proceeding from the heaviest to the lightest punishments.

chapter.title: Rǝ⊃eh
chapter.p: [22]Whereas if you carefully keep all these instructions that I instruct you and practice them: to love GOD your God, to follow all His ways, and to cleave to Him, [23]GOD will drive out all these nations from before you, and you will dispossess greater and mightier nations than you. [24]Every part of territory on which the sole of your foot treads will be yours; from the wilderness to the Lebanon, from the river — the river Euphrates — to the Mediter-ranean, will be your border. [25]No man will stand against you; GOD will put panic and the fear of you on all the land on which you will tread, as He promised you.

[26]Behold! I set before you today a blessing and a curse. [27]The blessing, that you observe the commandments of GOD your God which I instruct you today, [28]and the curse, if you do not observe the commandments of GOD your God, but turn away from the path which I direct you today, to follow after other gods which you have not known.

[29]When GOD your God brings you into the land which you go to possess, you will place the blessing upon Mount Gerizim, and the curse upon Mount Ebol. [30]These mountains are across the Jordan, toward the setting sun, in the land of the Canaanites who dwell in the plain opposite Gilgal, near ’Eloney Moreh. [31]For you are crossing the Jordan, coming to possess the land which GOD your God is giving you. When you possess it and dwell in it, [32]you must keep practicing all the decrees and the rules which I set before you today. [12:1]These are the decrees and the rules which you must keep, in the land which GOD the God of your fathers has given you to possess, all the days that you are on the earth. [12:2]You must utterly eradicate all the places in which the nations you are to dispossess, served their gods — on the high mountains, and on the hills, and under every leafy tree. [3]Tear down their altars, smash their monoliths, and burn their asherim in fire; topple the statues of their gods; so that you destroy their name from that place. [4]You shall not do so to GOD your God, [5]but only to the place which GOD your God chooses, from all your tribes, to put His Name — you will seek out His abode, and you will go there. [6]There you will bring your burnt-offerings, your festival sacrifices, tithes, your first fruit, your vows and pledges, and the firstlings of your herd and flock. [7]And there you will eat before GOD your God, and enjoy all your undertakings — you together with your households, with which GOD your God has blessed you. [8]You must not do at all as we are doing here at the present time, everyone whatever he pleases, [9]for you have not yet reached the rest and the inheritance, which GOD your God is giving you. [10]But when you cross the Jordan and settle in the land which GOD your God gives you to inherit, and He grants you tranquility from all your enemies around you, so that you will dwell in safety; [11]then at the place in which GOD your God chooses to allow His Name to abide, there will you bring all that I commanded you: your burnt-offerings, and your festival sacrifices, your tithes and your first fruit, and all the choice of your vows which you vow to GOD. [12]You will rejoice before GOD your God — you, and your sons, and your daughters, your men-servants, and maid-servants — together with the Levite, who is within your gates, because he has no portion nor allotment with you. [13]Be careful not to sacrifice your burnt-offerings in every place which you deem suitable; [14]but only in the place which GOD will choose, within one of your tribes; there will you sacrifice your burnt-offerings, and there will you do all as I have instructed you. [15]However, within all of your gates, whenever you have a personal desire, you may slaughter and eat flesh, according to the blessing which GOD your God granted you. The ritually impure and the ritually pure may partake of it, as of the gazelle and the deer. [16]But the blood must you not eat; you will pour it out upon the ground like water. [17]You are not allowed to eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, your wine and your oil, or the firstlings of your herd and flock, nor any of your vows which you vowed, nor your pledges, nor the offerings of your first fruit; [18]but you may eat it before GOD your God, in the place which GOD your God will choose — you, your son, your daughter, your man-servant, and your maid-servant, together with the Levite who is within your gates; and you will rejoice before GOD your God in all your undertakings. [19]Be careful not to forsake the Levite as long as you live in your land.

[20]when GOD your God enlarges your territory, as He has promised you, and you say: ’I will eat meat,’ because your appetite desires to eat meat, you may eat the meat anywhere you desire, [21]when the place in which GOD your God will choose to allow His Name to abide, will be too far for you. But you must slaughter your oxen and flocks, which GOD your God has given you, as I have commanded you. Then, you may eat them within your gates, anywhere you desire. [22]But you will eat it as the gazelle and deer are eaten; the ritually impure will eat it together with the ritually pure. [23]But be resolute not to eat the blood, for the blood is the life; you shall not eat the life with the flesh. [24]You must not eat it; pour it out on the ground as water. [25]You must not eat it, in order that it may be good for you — you, and your children after you — when you fulfill that which is right before GOD. [26]But when you have you consecrated animals and vow-offerings, you must carry and go to the place which GOD will choose; [27]You will offer your burnt-offerings, the flesh and the blood, on the altar of GOD your God. The blood of your [other] offerings is to be poured on the altar of GOD your God, and you may eat the meat. [28]Observe and heed all these words which I instruct you, in order that you may enjoy happiness — you and your descendants after you — everlastingly, for you will practice that which is good and right before GOD your God.

[29]When GOD your God cuts down before you the nations whom you go to dispossess, and after you dispossess them and you dwell in their land, [30]be careful lest you be ensnared by them after they have been destroyed from before you, and lest you inquire after their gods, saying: ‘In the way that these nations worshipped their gods, in that same manner will I act’. [31] You must not act thus toward GOD your God, for every hated abominable thing to GOD have they practiced toward their gods; they even set fire to their sons and their daughters for their gods. [13:1]All these words which I instruct you, you must observe to practice; you must not add to them, nor must you diminish from them.

[2]If a prophet, or a dreamer of dreams, arises among you, and he gives you a signal, or a marvel. [3]Even if this signal or marvel which he predicted to you were to come true, if he tells you: ‘Let us follow other gods, which you do not know, and let us worship them’; [4]you must not listen to this prophet, or to the dreamer of dreams. For GOD your God puts you to the test, to know whether you really love GOD your God with all your heart and with all your soul. [5]After GOD your God must you walk, Him must you revere, His commandments must you keep, His voice must you obey, Him must you serve, and to Him must you cleave. [6] And that prophet, or that dreamer of dreams, will be put to death, because he spoke rebellious against GOD your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt, and redeemed you from the house of slavery — to sidetrack you from the path which GOD your God commanded to walk. You must remove the evil from your midst.

[7]If your brother, the son of your mother, or your son, or daughter, or your bosom wife, or your friend whom you love like yourself, entices you secretly saying: ‘Let us go and worship other gods,’ of which you do not know, neither you, nor your fathers; [8]from among the gods of the people around you, either near or far away from you, even from one end of the world to the other end of the world, [9]do not assent to him, nor accept his words. You must not spare him, nor pity him, neither must you cover him up, [10]but you must put him to death. Let your hand be first to put him to death, and afterward the hand of the people. [11]Stone him to death, because he attempted to draw you away from GOD your God, Who brought you out from the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery. [12]Thus all Israel will hear and fear, and will not do any more wickedness, such as this, in your midst.

[13]If you should hear tell, that in one of the towns that GOD your God is giving you to dwell in, [14]some scoundrels have come out from among you and enticed the inhabitants of their town saying, ‘Let us go and worship other gods,’ which you have not known; [15]you must inquire and search and investigate thoroughly. If it be true and the thing is substantiated, that such abomination was done in your midst, [16]you must surely strike the inhabitants of that town with the sword. Destroy it utterly and all that is in there, even its cattle, by the sword. [17]Gather all its spoil in the midst of its thoroughfare, and burn in fire the city and all its spoil, entirely, for GOD your God, and it must remain a heap for ever, never to be rebuilt. [18]Nothing must remain in your possession of the condemned city, in order that GOD may turn from the fierceness of His anger, and grant you mercy, have compassion upon you, and multiply you as He has promised your forefathers, [19]for you will follow the voice of GOD your God to keep all His commandments which I instruct you today, to practice what is right before GOD your God.

[14:1]You are children of GOD your God. You, therefore, must not cut your flesh nor make any baldness on your head between your eyes for the dead. [2]Because you are a people consecrated to GOD your God, and GOD has chosen you from all the people that are upon the earth to be His treasure,

[3]you must not eat any abominable thing. [4]These are the beasts that you may eat: the ox, the sheep kid and the goat kid; [5]the gazelle, the deer, the roebuck, the wild goat, the antelope, the wild-ox and the mountain-sheep, [6]and every beast whose hoofs are split, completely cleft in two, and ruminating, among the beasts, you may eat. [7]But do not eat those that only ruminate, or only have split hoofs. The camel, the hare, and the rabbit although they ruminate, their hoofs are not split, and they are ritually impure for you. [8]Also the swine, although its hoofs are split, but no cud, he is ritually impure for you; you must not eat of their flesh, and their carcasses will you not touch.
[9]Of all the following things which are in water, may you eat: whatever has fins and scales, you may eat; [10]But whatever has no fins and scales you must not eat; it is ritually impure for you.

[11]Every ritually pure bird you may eat. [12]These are the ritually impure which you must not eat: the nesher, the peres, and the ‘ozniyyah. [13]the ra’ah, the ’ayyah, and the dayyah of their species, [14]every ‘orev of its species; [15]the bat-hayya‘na, the taḥmas, the shaḥaf, and the neṣ of its species; [16]the kos, and the yanshuf, and the tinshemet, [17]the qa’a, and the raḥama, and the shalakh, [18]the ḥasida, and the ’anafa of its species, and the dukhifat, and the ‘aṭallef. [19]All winged swarming things are ritually unclean for you; they must not be eaten. [20]Of every ritually pure winged thing you may eat. [21]You must not eat anything that died by itself; you may give it for food to the resident alien who is within your gates, or sell it to a foreigner — for you are a consecrated people to GOD your God. You must not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.

[22]You must set aside the tithe from all the produce of your seed, which the field goes out year after year. [23]You will eat the tithe of your grain and wine and oil, and the firstlings of your oxen and flocks, before GOD your God, in the place where He will choose His Name to dwell, in order that you learn to revere GOD your God always. [24]If the distance be too long for you so that you are not able to carry it, because the place where GOD your God has chosen to place His Name will be far from you, because GOD your God has blessed you, [25]you may exchange it for money, take the money in your hand, and go to the place which GOD your God will choose, [26]and you may spend the money for whatever your appetite wishes — for meat of oxen, or of flocks, wine, or alchoholic beverage, and of whatever your heart desires. And you may eat it there before GOD your God, and enjoy it, you and your household. [27]But you must not forsake the Levite who resides within your gates, for he has no portion nor allotment with you.

[28]At the boundary of three years you must bring out all the tithes of your produce of that year, and leave it at your gates. [29]The Levite, who has no portion nor allotment with you, will come; and the alien, the orphan, and the widow who are within your gates, they will eat and be satisfied, so that GOD your God may bless you in all your undertakings which you undertake.

[15:1]At the boundary of seven years you will arrange a release. [2]This is the manner of the release: every debt-possessor will cancel the debt which he holds of his neighbor; he must not press his neighbor, his brother, for payment, because He has proclaimed a release to GOD. [3]You may press the foreigner for payment, but whatever you have of your brother is released. [4]However, there will be no needy among you, because GOD will surely bless you in the land which GOD your God is giving you for an inheritance to possess. [5]If only you wholeheartedly head the voice of GOD your God, to keep and to practice all these commandments which I instruct you today. [6]For GOD your God will bless you as He has promised you; you will secure loans to many nations, but you will not have to borrow; you will rule over many nations, but they will not rule over you.

[7]If there be among you a needy man, one of your brothers in one of your city gates in your land which GOD your God is giving you, do not toughen your heart, nor shut your hand from your needy brother; [8]but you must open your hand to him; and you must secure a loan to him sufficient for whatever he needs that he may lack. [9]Be careful not to have a base thought in your mind, saying: ‘The seventh year, the year of release, is approaching’, and your eye be mean against your needy brother, refusing to assist him. If he will cry against you to GOD, the sin will be yours. [10]You must give, give to him and your spirit must not be troubled by giving to him, because on account of this very thing GOD your God will bless you in all your labors and in all your undertakings. [11]The needy will not be absent in the midst of your land. Therefore, I am instructing you, as follows: You must surely open your hand to your brother, to your poor, and to the needy of your land.

[12]If your Hebrew brother be sold to you, whether male or female, he may serve you six years, and in the seventh year you must set him free. [13]When you set him free, do not let him go empty handed: [14]Supply him with a bonus from your flock, from your threshing-floor, and from your winepress; give to him of that with which GOD your God has blessed you. [15]Remember that you were a slave in Egypt and GOD your God redeemed you; therefore I command you this thing today. [16](However, if he tells you ‘I do not want to leave you, for I love you and your house-hold,’ because he is happy with you; [17]then you take an awl, and pierce his ear at the door, and he will be your servant forever.) So shall you do even to your maid-servant. [18] You must not begrudge him when you send him free from you, for he served you six years, twice the hire of a hireling; and GOD your God will bless you in all that you do.

[19]All the firstling males that are born in your herd and in your flock must be consecrated to GOD your God: you must not do any work with the firstlings of your ox, nor shear off the wool of the firstlings of your sheep. [20]You must eat them annually before GOD your God, in the place which GOD will choose, you and your household. [21]But if it has a defect, lameness, or blindness, or any serious defect, you must not sacrifice it to GOD your God. [22]You may eat it within your gates, ritually impure and ritually pure, as the gazelle and the deer. [23]Only you must not eat its blood; you must pour it on the ground like water.

[16:1]Observe the month of the Spring, and make the Passover to GOD your God, for in the month of the Spring, at night, GOD your God brought you out from Egypt. [2]You will offer the Passover sacrifice to GOD your God of the flock, and oxen, in the place where GOD chooses His Name to abide. [3]You must not eat leaven on it. For seven days shall you eat Matzoth, the bread of affliction, on it, for in haste did you leave Egypt, so that you will remember the day of your departure from Egypt all the days of your life. [4]No food of fermentation of yours shall be seen within your territory for seven days, and none of the flesh which you offer on the eve of the first day shall be left over till the morning. [5]You may not slaughter the Paschal sacrifice within any of your city gates that GOD your God is giving you; [6]but at the place where GOD your God shall choose His Name to abide, there will you slaughter the Paschal sacrifice toward evening — at sunset — at the season when you went out of Egypt, [7]you will cook it and eat it in the place which GOD your God will choose; and in the morning, you may return to your tents. [8]You shall eat Matzo for six days, and on the seventh day of the festival there must be a solemn assembly for GOD your God, you must not do work on it.

[9]You shall count for you seven weeks. From when the first standing grain is reaped will you begin to count seven weeks, [10]then you will celebrate the Feast of Weeks, for the sake of GOD your God with a tribute of a freewill offering of your arm, which you will give according to what GOD your God blessed you. [11]You will rejoice before GOD your God, at the place where GOD your God will choose His Name to abide; you, your son, your daughter, your man-servant and your maid-servant; and the Levite who is in your city gates, and the stranger, the orphan, and the widow, who are in your midst. [12]You must remember that you were a slave in Egypt, and you must observe to practice these decrees.
chapter.ftnote: [22] Whereas I.e., concerning that which I mentioned earlier — that you would “perish quickly from upon the good land” — realize that you will not even arrive there in the first place, and you will not conquer it, if you do not observe GOD’s commandments. to love in one’s heart. to walk in all His ways and neither stray, nor turn back cleave to Him upon expiring (this is a great mystery).
[26] Behold [singular] Moshe addresses every individual.

[27] The blessing, that you will observe I.e., through your observing, you become blessed. A blessing is an increase in good, whereas a curse [Hebrew: qәlalah] is a reduction (from “degrade” [Hebrew: qalah]).
[29] you will place the blessing orally (as in “he will put them on the head of the he-goat” [Leviticus 16:21]).

[30] across the Jordan opposite the wilderness. toward the setting sun meaning, If you travel westward, you will find them. in the land of the Canaanites who dwell in the plain for there are Canaanites who dwell in the hills. opposite Gilgal Since the mountains are extensive, Scripture specifies which part of the mountains. The phrase opposite Gilgal [which name did not exist until the time of Joshua [Joshua 5:9] — Translator] must be understood the same way as “he pursued as far as Dan” [Genesis 14:14]: either it was written prophetically, or there are two places with the same name. opposite meaning, “facing”. כEloney Moreh the same that was mentioned in Abraham’s time [Genesis 12:6]. Scripture will specify later the exact wording of the blessing and of the curse [27:15ff].
[31] The passage For you are crossing means: You are about to begin observing the commandments, whereby the land will become a permanent inheritance for you.

[12:2] You must utterly eradicate all the places… The grammarian Rabbi Yona ibn Janaḥ said that the phrase their gods is missing a vav, as if to say “the places where they worshipped, [and] their gods …”. But his explanation contributes nothing. Rather, the phrase is the object of the verb they worshipped. The word leafy, like the word “tranquil” [e.g., Isaiah 33:20], always appears with two nun’s. Its meaning is related to “green” [Job 8:16].
[3] their asherim these are trees. destroy their name so that it shall not be mentioned.
[4] You shall not do so to … I.e., you shall not sacrifice on the hills, nor on the mountains, but

[5] only on the place where He shall set His Name. to put His Name Compare, “wherever I case My Name to be pronounced” [Exodus 20:21]. You will seek out His abode denoting the locale, in the sense of “the place where His glory dwells” [cf. Psalms 26:8].
[7] there you (i.e., the Kohanim and the Levites) will eat.

[8] But you must not do as we are doing here
After the death of Aaron — since they used to travel from one encampment to another — a man might offer, e.g., a burnt-offering, in whatever encampment he desired; or, one man might offer the firstborn of his flock, while another man did not so offer — because the obligation in each case is dependent on the land of Israel.
I do not agree with this interpretation. Rather,
Moshe’s meaning is that they were not all completely dedicated to GOD. The reason he can say we [thereby including even himself — Translator] is that there were many commandments concerning, e.g., burnt-offerings, which could not be fulfilled except in the land of Israel (for so it is written [Numbers 15:2]).

[9] the rest Figuratively, a condition from which their descendants will not stray. The same interpretation can be given to the word “inheritance”. Actually, however, the word rest is to be understood
[10] in connection with the phrase He grants you tranquility; and the word “inheritance” denotes the time when you will dwell in safety.
[11] the choice of your vows One is obliged to satisfy his vows with the choicest of his animals [Yoma 34b].
[12] Scripture repeats the word you will rejoice [cf. :7], in order to introduce the principle that you must gladden the Levite, because he has no portion as you yourself have.
[13] Scripture repeats the idea of in every place which you deem suitable [cf. :8] in order

[15] to exclude meat of luxury. Since peace-offerings are holy, and since a ritually impure person who eats holy meat incurs excision, Scripture clarifies that meat of luxury may be eaten by the ritually impure and the ritually pure. like the gazelle and like the deer which are never offered on the Altar — and hence a gazelle’s suet, as well as a deer’s suet, may be eaten (this supports my previous assertion [comment on Leviticus 7:23ff.]; but we rely primarily on our ancestral tradition [Ḥullin 117a]).

[17] to eat within your gates the tithe of your grain… Scripture addresses the Levites (and, according to many, also the common Israelites, apropos the second tithe); similarly in the phrase the firstlings of your herd and flock, Scripture addresses the Kohanim. The Levites, as well as the Kohanim, are included among “Israel” in general (as in “I commanded you” [3:18], wherein Moshe addresses only two and one-half tribes). Compare “however, you must redeem…” [Numbers 18:15], which is addressed to all Israel, but which only applies to someone who has a firstborn that he is obliged to redeem. Thus, to eat within your gates…

[18] you may eat it before GOD your God can only apply to someone who is obliged to eat it. ¶ The Dissenters have said that there are two firstborns: 1) the firstborn who “opens the womb” [Exodus 13:12] and 2) the “firstborn of the flock”; but there is no need to reply to their nonsense. Others among them have said that this passage concerns the firstborn [15:22] [Bekhorot 32b] and the tithe [Yevamot 85bff] that an ordinary Israelite may eat — that it may be eaten even in the “chosen place”. But this is the opposite of what Scripture says!
[20] because your appetite desires to eat meat i.e., if your appetite desires to eat meat. This law has already been mentioned [:15], but Scripture repeats it here to add the passage
[21] when the place will be too far. This includes any place outside of the land of Canaan: its status is the same as that of any place within your gates.
[23] I have already explained the phrase for the blood is the life [comment on Genesis 9:4: comment on Leviticus 17:15].

[25] that it may be good for you One should not incorporate the soul of a beast, and thereby adulterate one’s own soul. Since both the soul, and the form of the body, are formed in the image of the father, Scripture accordingly continues your children after you.
[26] consecrated animals e.g., your burnt-offerings, your peace-offerings, and your vows. carry meaning, you must bring them to the chosen place.

[27] you may eat the meat Scripture addresses the Kohanim, in the case of a firstling, or a sin-offering, or a guilt-offering. In the case of a peace-offering, only the thigh and the breast are meant, the greater part of it being eaten by an ordinary Israelite.
[28] observe and heed to spill the blood at the side of the Altar.
[29] When He cuts down This passage is connected to the passage “When He enlarges…” [:20] — if they are not victorious over the other nations, then He cannot enlarge the borders.

[30] The word and lest introduces an elliptical construction, as if Scripture had said “and be careful … lest you inquire after their gods, in order to act as they act, saying…”. in that same manner will I act in worshiping GOD, thinking that you thereby do well. However,
[31] you must not act thus, because all of their actions are abhorrent to GOD (as evidenced by the subsequent explanation, they even set fire to their sons…). Rather,
[13:1] you must observe that which I have commanded you.

[2] if a prophet arises among you The meaning of among you is that a prophet must be from the nation of Israel. The common thread connecting this passage with the previous passage is the prohibition against idolatry (the burning of children [12:31] was an idolatrous practice). The word prophet here denotes someone who claims that GOD, or a messenger of GOD, spoke to him while awake. The other possibility is that it occurred in a dream. Some say, that the prophet discussed here is likely one of the “thieves of GOD’s words” [cf. Jeremiah 23:30] — to wit: A true prophet announces that a certain miracle will come, to justify him; someone else overhears this, and then asserts that the miracle applies to himself. Others say, that we do not believe him, even if the signal or marvel comes to pass, because he says things that are contrary to logic. In my opinion, the Hebrew words signal and marvel here have the sense of “sign” [and not any supernatural event — Translator]: 1) The words of Isaiah provide evidence for this interpretation. He said “Behold, I, and the children whom GOD has given me, are for signs and for portents” [Isaiah 8:18] (the prophet’s own sign was “…just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot…” [Isaiah 20:3]; the sons’ signs were their names, each being named after an event which was to occur in his lifetime, i.e., “Immanuכel” [Isaiah 7:14], “Maher-Shalal-Ḥash-Baz” [Isaiah 8:3], and “Shәכar-Yashuv” [Isaiah 7:3]). 2) With respect to plagues, Scripture says “They will serve you as signs and proofs” [28:46]. Many similar examples exist.
[4] test in that He let him be, and did not kill him. GOD tests people to reveal the virtue of him who is tested.

[5] after GOD your God must you walk you must imitate His acts, to the best of your ability, and pursue His ways. Him must you revere fearing to question “Why is this?” His commandments must you keep i.e., the commandments which are ends in themselves. His voice must you obey i.e., the commandments which remind us of those ends. Him must you serve in action. and to Him must you cleave in your heart — in the first life, and in the afterlife.

[6] he spoke rebellious i.e., he spoke rebellious words. Compare, “in the multitude of counsellors, [counsel] is established” [Proverbs 15:22]. The derivation of the Hebrew word rebellious [Hebrew: sarah] could be that he turned away [Hebrew: sarah] from GOD Who commanded us to turn away from idol-worship, or it comes from “insubordinate [Hebrew: sorer] and rebellious” [21:18] — and the latter etymology is correct (it would thus be appropriate for the resh to be vocalized with a dagesh). ¶ Scripture repeats the sense of Who brought you out in redeemed you, for the sake of emphasis. I have already explained the word you must remove [comment on Numbers 24:22].

[7] If you brother entices i.e., if even your own brother. the son of your mother who was in the same womb as you. The mother represents the substance, whereas the father represents the form. Only a few people, though, can discern the form.

[9] do not assent to him in your heart’s belief. nor accept his words in action. you must not spare him from being killed. you must not cover him by refraining from action. Rather, you must reveal the matter, so that witnesses will come and hear it from his own mouth (for so it is written [17:6]) —

[10] and then you must kill him. Let your hand be first Were it not for the tradition, it would seem that this is addressed to each one of the witnesses [cf. 17:7] [the halakha [Sanhedrin 67a] is that it is the witnesses who begin the stoning, not the people subjected to the enticement, whenever they are distinct from one another — Translator].
[11] Stone him Scripture specifies the form of death.
[15] The terms inquire and search and investigate are well explained in the words of our Sages, of blessed memory [Sanhedrin 44aff].
[17] entirely All of it belongs to GOD your God, i.e., you must burn it in fire for the glory of GOD. heap [Hebrew: tel] from “a high and lofty [Hebrew: talul] mountain” [Ezekiel 17:22].
[18] in order that GOD may turn from the fierceness of His anger and not destroy you in the city’s iniquity.
[19] The verse for you will follow… means: So will you do, if you seek to practice what is right in His eyes. This passage is juxtaposed to the subsequent passage

[14:1] on account of the enticers to idolatry (be they brother, or son, or father, or the inhabitants of the “seduced city”) — it is forbidden to mourn over them at all, and certainly to cut one’s flesh, which is forbidden for any dead person. cut your flesh ([Hebrew: titgodәdu] from “upon all the hands shall be gashes [Hebrew: gәdudot]” [Jeremiah 48:37]) for the same reason as “any incision for the soul” [Leviticus 19:28]. nor make any baldness as the other nations do, to this very day. ¶ Children Once you understand that you are children of GOD, and He loves you more than a father loves his child, then you will not cut your flesh over anything that He does, for everything that he does is good. Even if you do not understand it — as small children do not not understand their father’s actions, yet they trust him — you should yourselves act likewise,
[2] because you are a consecrated people and you are not like the other Canaanites. Accordingly you should not act as they act. The reason for the juxtaposition of this passage with the passage

[3] you must not eat any abominable thing is: You are to be a holy nation, in your hearts and in your mouths. You must thus be distinguishable from the other nations, so that anyone who sees you will recognize you. Accordingly you must not make yourselves bald over the dead [cf. :1], nor may you eat just any animal — for, if you are to be a holy nation, it is not fitting that you should eat that which is defiled, and thereby defile your souls. any abominable thing i.e., anything which is abhorrent to a refined spirit, such as the vermin of the earth [cf. comment on Leviticus 18:22].
[4] the ox [and] Scripture omits the connective vav the sheep kid and the goat kid The word “kid” can, in Hebrew, be applied both to the goat species and the sheep species.
[5] The meanings of the terms up till the gazelle and the deer are commonly known; the remaining five terms require the Tradition [Sa’adya Gaon on this verse].
[8] but no cud Scripture employs brevity, and omits either the word “chews” (i.e., “but chews no cud”) or the word “has” (i.e., “but has no cud”).
[9] I have already explained the words fins and scales [comment on Leviticus 11:9].

[11] bird is a generic term, as I explained earlier [comment on Genesis 15:10], when I pointed out that “turtle-dove” [Genesis 15:9] and “pigeon” [Genesis 15:9] were two individual species within the same generic term. Similarly,
[13] dayyah and raכah are specific terms classified under the more general term “daכah” [Leviticus 11:14]; here Scripture gives additional detail.
[20] every ritually pure winged thing e.g., the locust.

[21] you must not eat anything that died by itself whether a bird, or a beast. to the resident alien who is within your gates and has not converted to Judaism. The person to whom one sells it may either be a stranger who does not dwell in the land, or he may have the status that I have explained [see comment on Exodus 22:20]. Because this passage concerns meat, it is connected to the passage you must not cook a kid…, as I have previously explained [comment on Exodus 23:19; the reference is to an earlier commentary on Exodus, known as the Perush Haqqaṣar — Translator]. This passage, in turn, is connected to the passage

[22] You must set aside the tithe because Scripture has informed us that one may not eat a ritually impure bird, nor a ritually impure beast, nor a beast that has died by itself — thereby concluding the discussion of meat. With respect to grain, on the other hand, there is a consecrated portion which may not be eaten except in the appropriate place. ¶ The Spaniard Rabbi Yәhudah HaLevy — may he be for us a light from above!1 — has said that the phrase which the field goes out year after year modifies the word seed (and thus denotes the seed that one takes out into the field). In my opinion, the meaning is more straightforward: it denotes the produce that the field brings forth. If you should object that Scripture uses the term “goes out”, which is an intransitive verb, I shall show you “the city that brought forth [literally: went forth] one thousand, shall have one hundred left” [Amos 5:3] in which the verb “shall have left [singular]” is definitive proof of the other verb’s transitivity. ¶ Our Sages, of blessed memory, have asserted [Sifrey on this verse] that this verse describes the Second Tithe. Understand that if you count upward, you begin with One; if you count downward, you begin with Ten. This is the mystery of the first-born, and of the tithe [cf. comment on Leviticus 27:32ff.]. Understand that the number One is in a class by itself. So is the number Ten (which corresponds to the number One), because it is both the beginning of the tens, and the end of the units. All the other unary numbers are contained within them, between one and the other. Because One and Ten are the fundamental quantities, they and the numbers midway between them — i.e., Five and Six — are called “round numbers”. Accordingly, the silent letters in the Hebrew alphabet [’alef, heh, vav, and yod — Translator] are those that correspond to these four quantities; and among them are the letters that form the Glorious and Awesome Name [cf. comment on Exodus 3:15].

[23] …the firstlings of your oxen i.e., he who is fit to eat them will eat them, as I have explained [comment on 12:17]. The obvious meaning of in order that you learn is: When you are staying in the holy place, they will teach you. But a non-obvious meaning is in the sense of “a well-broken heifer” [Hosea 10:11], meaning “you will become accustomed to”. I believe that the latter interpretation is the correct one. The tithe mentioned here is the object of the verb
[25] you may exchange. The word in your hand means, entrusted into your hands.

[26] or alchoholic beverage made from honey, or from dates, or from wheat, or from barley. whatever your heart desires e.g., fruit. you and your household you and your sons are obliged, whereas the rest of your household are permitted. The commandment to observe the three festivals is binding only upon males [Exodus 23:17]; but those women will be rewarded who, like the wives of כElqanah, [I Samuel 1:3ff.], go on pilgrimage to the appointed place.

[27] the Levite who resides within your gates denotes any member of the Tribe of Levi. You will be rewarded if you do not forsake them, but rather, if you give them commensurate to what you can afford. The most plausible interpretation is that Scripture is discussing the first tithe. Having just mentioned the second tithe, Scripture now says: Do not think that you fulfill your duty with only the second tithe. within your gates The first tithe should be given to him who resides within your gates. One should not say, “Since he will always be with me, I shall send this to a different Levite”, or “I have already given to him”.

[28] The passage at the boundary of three years discusses the Pauper’s Tithe. During this year, one should not set apart the Second Tithe [Rosh HaShana 12b]. Some say, though, that one should set apart all three tithes. The Dissenters assert that the passage “you must set aside…” [:22] denotes the first tithe (and that the passage “take the money in your hand…” [:22] is addressed to the Levites, just as the phrase “the firstlings of your herds” [:23] is addressed to the Kohanim), and that there is a second tithe only every three years, known as the Pauper’s Tithe — but we shall rely on our ancestral tradition. boundary here denotes the beginning. Similarly,

[15:1] At the boundary of seven years you will arrange a release denotes the beginning of the year, as is corroborated by the passage of “assemble the people” [31:12]. The passage is connected to the previous one because, having mentioned that the Pauper’s Tithe belongs to the Levite, and the alien, and the orphan, and the widow [cf. 14:29], it is now logical to discuss the general release. release [Hebrew: shmiṭṭah] from “drop her” [Hebrew: shimṭuhah] [II Kings 9:33]: i.e., they released her, and she fell.

[2] The word debt [Hebrew: masheh] has the same form as the word “staff’ [Hebrew: maṭṭeh], and in my opinion is a noun (according to many, however, it is a verb [meaning “lending” — Translator]). The word possessor is here used in the same sense as in “wisdom preserves the lives of them that have it” [Ecclesiastes 7:12], or “takes away the life of its owners” [Proverbs 1:19], denoting the person to whom something belongs. hold is a transitive verb; the borrower is said to be “beholden to”. press [Hebrew: yiggos̀] i.e., “oppress”, as in “you exact [Hebrew: tingos̀u] all your payments” [Isaiah 58:3] (in which one can see the nun, which normally disappears in the future form of a peh-nun verb). a release to GOD i.e., in honor of GOD, Who has given the creditor wealth. The association here with GOD is due to the earlier statement “it is the Sabbath of GOD” [Leviticus 25:2].
[3] You may press the foreigner for payment i.e., it is permissible.

[4] However… The sense of this passage is: Know that there might be no need for that which I have commanded you concerning not pressing your brother for payment; for there will be no one among you in need of your lending to him
[5] if all (or the majority) of Israel hearkens unto the voice of GOD. Rather,

[6] you will all secure loans from many nations (meaning, that you will take their “security” — i.e., “collateral” — for the money that you will give them, which they need in order to engage in commerce). Indeed, as long as you remain upright, you will rule over them. Nevertheless, the command does apply

[7] If there be among you a needy man. Accordingly, Scripture informs us that “the needy will not be absent in the midst of your land” [:11]; He knew that the generation would come in which the majority of people are not innocent. do not toughen your heart You must speak kind words to him. shut means “to close”1 when the verb is in the qal form. needy [Hebrew: ⊃evyon] Some say that the word is related to “he did not want [Hebrew: ⊃avah] to let them go” [Exodus 10:27] (thereby attributing to it the same form as is shown by the Hebrew words “lofty [Hebrew: ⊂elyon]”, “hideaway [Hebrew: ḥevyon]”, and “logic [Hebrew: higgayon]”, whose triliteral roots are ⊂-l-h, ḥ-v-h, and h-g-h, respectively), denoting one who is in want of everything, due to his great need.

[8] You must open employs a verbal noun. ¶ In fact, every verb that is not preceded by the verbal noun is in reality an elliptical construct. But the homiletical explanation [Bava Meṣi‘a 31b] [that it applies to the poor of other cities as well as to of one’s own — Translator] is also attractive. open your hand to him applies to someone who has nothing, as opposed to you must secure a loan to him — you must give him of yours, in exchange for his collateral (the verb “secure a loan” means “take in exchange for a security”).

[9] The word base [Hebrew: bliyya⊂al] is a noun. Some say, however, that it is a compound word, suggestive of a prayer that does not ascend [Hebrew: ya⊂al], nor increase, nor endure. your eye be mean employs an ‘ayin-vav verb, of the same form as “she returns to her father’s house” [Leviticus 22:13].

[10] on account of [literally: “in rolling over”] i.e., “for the reason of” [literally: “in turning over”]. Compare “to turn this matter the other way” [II Samuel 14:20]. ¶ The reason behind this verse’s assertion is that all of our individual bodies are nothing more than parts of an integrated Whole. give, give indicating that if you give to him, GOD will then increase your possessions.

[11] I have already explained the needy will not be absent in the midst of your land [comment on 15:7]. You must first give to your brother (i.e., your blood relative), before giving to your poor (i.e., the poor in your family); and the needy of your land have precedence over the needy of another land. The common theme which connects this passage

[12] with the passage If your Hebrew brother be sold to you is the idea of “supply him with a bonus” [:14]. I have already defined the term Hebrew brother [comment on Exodus 21:2]. or female The case is when a man sells his daughter to be a maidservant [Mekhilta on Exodus 21:7].
[13] I have already explained the word empty [comment on Genesis 31:42].
